caption:
棒棒鸡 Bang Bang Chicken or ::Szechuan Chinese Chicken Salad:: as I call it,  is the sort of dish you would imagine as a cold appetiser dish at a Chinese family's Super Bowl Party. Salty, sweet, spicy and just a tad tangy from the sauces smothered over. It can be tossed together much earlier in the game, the blank canvas of chicken breast providing the perfect platform for the 怪味 "strange flavour" sauce to shine. Its name is derived from the sound of the rolling pin bearing down as it flattens the poached chicken and paving the way for easy shredding. Alternatively you can do it the good old fashioned way, with your finger tips if you're not one to favour the ruckus.

Bang Bang Chicken (Szechuan style)
Makes enough for 4

A 225g chicken breast poached in 2 cups of water with 3 slices of ginger and 2 scallions knotted together (simmer on a rolling boil for 6 mins, turn off the heat and leave, covered in pot for 15 mins. Remove from pot into ice bath)
1/2 cucumber (julienned) - I used a zucchini
1/2 cup chicken stock (reserved from the poaching chicken liquids earlier)
2 tablespoon light soy sauce
1/2 tablespoon dark soy sauce
2 Tablespoon black vinegar
1 tablespoon chili oil + dried chili
1 tablespoon sugar
1 tablespoon sesame oil
2 tablespoon toasted sesame seeds
1 TSP Sichuan peppercorns, grounded
1/2 TSP salt
2 scallions, chopped

Poach your chicken as instructed above. Shred or bang bang if you prefer.

Lay your julienned cucumber on the bottom of the dish followes by the chicken shreds. Prepare the sauce in a small pot, chicken stock, sugar, sauces, sesame oil, seeds and scallions. It's gonna look like a mad tasty party already.

Pour over the chicken and cucumber. Toss to coat when you're ready to eat. Rice or cold noodles, it's all very complimentary and also perfect for the sweltering weather.

Recipe adapted from the awesome folks at @thewoksoflife 🤟

#sskitchendisasters #vscofood #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #burpple #BudgetTenDollars

caption:
Solidly engineered kimchi from @lees_kimchi_sg finds a place in today's lunch menu - Korean pork kimchi stir-fry. It is a mess of a dish; juicy strips of pork nicely balanced with gentle hits of acidity from the fermented cabbage. Still slightly crunchy onions provide occasional respite from the rather 'soft' textural plight.

A dish that takes me back to my days of living in Strathfield in Sydney instantly. Those were times of beer towers, late night fried chicken and cheap Korean fringe trims. Good times.

Kimchi Pork stir-fry
Makes a mountain good to feed 4

300g thin sliced pork (you can use belly, I did the shabu shabu pork from @yakiniku_plaza)
400g kimchi
1 onion, sliced thinly
1 Tablespoon red miso
1 tablespoon soy sauce
1 TSP paprika
1 TSP chili powder
1 tablespoon sugar
2 tablespoon of water
Spring onions and sesame seeds for garnish

In a wok, fry up the pork in a little bit of oil. Combine the red miso, soy sauce, chili powder and paprika to make a sauce. Alternatively you can use a heaping tablespoon of gochujang if you have at home. Add that to the wok with your kimchi and stir fry till 60% cooked. Throw in your sliced onions and sugar and stir it a little. Add some water to the pan and put the lid on for about 1 minute. Fry for another minute and plate up. Garnish with sesame seeds and spring onions and serve with white rice or lettuce leaves as wraps. From wok to the table in just under 6 minutes. What's not to like?

#sskitchendisasters #food52 #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #BudgetTenDollars #StayHomeWithAscott

caption:
While attempting to empty the fridge yesterday, I conceived an anything-but-the-kitchen-sink Swiss roll. It's a scratchy list of things that tried to make their debut on there: salted caramel, butterscotch sauce, lingonberry jam and gianduja spread - bits and bobs from deliveries past. Whatever it is, the red carpet of spreads turned out glorious. Hip hip hooray!

Easy-peasy Swiss roll
Requires one 13 X 9 inch pan

70g plain flour
13g cornstarch
1/4 TSP baking powder
3 large eggs (I used the awesome #CheonggyewonEgg ones) - seperated
80g caster sugar
2.5 tablespoon vegetable oil
2 tablespoon milk

Filling - raid your fridge

Preheat your oven to 180°C. Line a rectangle pan 9 X 13 inch with baking paper. Let the sides stick out.

Sift the flour, cornstarch and baking powder into a bowl.

In your mixing bowl, whisk yolks, oil and milk with 40g caster sugar till light and fluffy. It will take about 6 minutes on the highest speed to achieve pale yellow state.

Fold in the flour mixture gently till there are no visible lumps.

Using a clean bowl, whisk the whites and 40g of sugar till stiff peaks.

Fold in the whites into the yolk mixture in 3 parts. Gently please. It is okay to see streaks of whites at this point. Continue till you get a homogeneous mix. Light and airy

Spread it out on your lined baking pan, making sure it's as even as you possible master (we're not perfect). Give it a light tap on a flat surface to expel the large bubbles. Place the tray on a larger tray with a cup of water poured in and bake that for 15 minutes.

Remove the cake from the oven once 15 minutes is over. Pry at the overhangs and flip out on to a new baking paper almost immediately. Slice off the edges. Spread whatever you want on the underside and proceed to roll up tightly with the aid of the baking paper. Allow to cool in its wrapped state for 15 minutes before slicing and eating.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #StayHomeWithAscott #BudgetTenDollars

caption:
Seven o'clock this morning with blurry eyes, I toasted slices of altamura bread splashed with extra virgin olive oil on a warm griddle pan. My gentle suggestion of eggs on toast met with luke warm responses at first, but by seven-thirty, all that greet me are yolk stained skid marks on white ceramic plates. I chased this with a bonus toast enlivened with nutella. Who says you can't have dessert at breakfast too?

Bread has always been my carb ride or die and I'm blessed throughout this circuit breaker to traverse the doughy realms from ultra soft milk buns (@sulyntan) to chewy bagels (@breadyard) . @Braci.sg's traditional Altamura bread is a Italian classic from the Puglia region with a PDO status (products with protected designation of origin) - a humble 4 ingredient bread; It is highly intolerant of poor handling. The dark crusted beauty that emerged from Braci's oven is a notch above the rest, though I admit my inexperience may have swayed my opinion. Nutty from the chew and just porous enough to smuggle oil and other delicious sauces.

Top tips: if you've got loaves you can't quite finish fast enough. Slice them immediately and freeze. Their shelf lives improve dramatically, at least 3 months, me thinks or till your carb monsters claim their last victim.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #SGUnited #savefnbsg #bracisg #BraciACasa #altamurabread #SihanSayDaBaoWhat

caption:
When it comes to my father's favourite afternoon snackages, it's easy to zero in on the big three: bubur cha cha, ondeh ondeh and Kueh salat. Notice the similarities? 🌴 // So this afternoon, away from prying eyes, I set my sights on making these elusive treats (which I now know better to purchase instead). The aftermath was all but empty plates and little grunts of gluttony that ensued. Worth it getting green dough underneath your finger nails? Yes. You might want to solicit some help though.

Kueh Ondeh Ondeh
Makes about 25 - 30

250g glutinous rice flour
1 tbsp brown sugar
250ml water blended with 5 pieces of pandan leaf chopped up
1 tbsp oil

100 gula melaka

150g grated coconut
Pinch of salt

Go ahead and steam your grated coconut combined with the salt for about 10 minutes. Remove and let cool.

Meantime make your dough by blending water together with the pandan leaves and putting that through a fine sieve. Making sure to press out all the pandan juice. Heat that in a pot till almost simmering.

Combine your glutinous rice flour and brown sugar. Making a well in the middle. Pour in the warm pandan juice and work it using chopsticks to form a paste. As larger crumbs start to form, pour in the oil and continue to work it till it's cool enough to maneuver with your fingers. Knead the dough till smooth and less sticky to the touch. Rest the dough underneath a damp towel.

Go ahead and chop your gula melaka into  tiny chunks. Set aside and please resist the urge to snack.

Measure out 13 - 15g pieces of dough. Roll into a ball and using your thumb, press out an indentation in the center which you'll then fill with gula melaka. Pinch the seams to seal the sugar in and roll out again into a  smooth ball.

By this time, you should have a pot of water on a rolling boil ready. Plop your balls into the water and leave them in there till they start to float (6 - 7 mins) and using a sieve, rescue them and roll them around in the bowl of steamed coconut you had set aside just now.

Watch this babies disappear like lightning. //Swipe ➡️ for the video! ~~~
#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #BudgetTenDollars #ondehondeh

caption:
A burger a day keeps the doctor away. 🍔 I think. // And this time, feeling bougie, I decided to up the ante on the already delicious Pulled Pork from @sousvidelicious and house them in burger buns (recipe in the previous post) slathered with garlic aioli with a simple coleslaw.

I may not have achieved my 100% #homemade ambitions here but why try so hard when you can weigh in on the experts (@sousvidelicious 😉). Quote [SIHANCOOKS] to enjoy 15% off your order.
~~~
Coleslaw
Makes enough for 3 burgers

1/3 head of cabbage, finely shredded
1 carrot shredded
2 TSP apple cider vinegar or red wine vinegar
Ground black pepper
1 huge TSP of Dijon mustard
2 tablespoon mayonnaise
Sea salt to taste
Swig of olive oil

Shred up your veggies. Feel free to mix red cabbage and white. Combine it with the the apple cider vinegar, black pepper, olive oil and Dijon mustard. Use your hands to really incorporate it in. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Also add your mayonnaise and toss to combine.

I like to prepare my coleslaw an hour prior to assembling the burgers, leaving it in the fridge till ready to use. That way the flavours really get to know each other.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #burgersaremynemesis #weaccidentallyaburger #StayHomeWithAscott

caption:
#SihanSayDaBaoWhat ~ this recommendation comes as a breeze. Alcohol in cake? ~ come to mamma 🤟// @braci.sg has just launched their new concept Braci a Casa which involves some really creative Italian fare at your table. Aside from the irresistible Foie gras semifreddo starter, I'm really digging the Capri Tiramisù which clever inception of Japanese Yamazaki whisky got me taking an interest instantly.

You'll want to dissect the slice in layers. The mascarpone and chocolate cake layers delivering starkingly different 'feels', from light and spongy towards the top to a more serious, spiked rendition at the bottom. It's a sizable round of soft cake garnished with crispy filo and cocoa nib lace that disappears outrageously quickly.

Order via www.braci.sg/casa. I would steer you towards the DIY options for more hands-on, fun, sexy times in the kitchen prior to a stellar meal. Scampi tagliolini, yes please.

#bracisg #SGUnited #savefnbsg #burpple #michelindining #sgfoodies

caption:
Bok! Bok! Bitches! Satisfying my fried chicken cravings this afternoon with what  seems like a party platter for 2 of {Salted Egg Chicken}, all to myself. It's one of those things that I've caught on @timtimtokyo 's insanely delicious story feed that has been bugging me for ages. Well, I think those salted duck eggs have served their time on my kitchen counter. Today is the day.

Salted Egg Chicken
Makes enough for 2

400g of chicken thigh, boneless, cut into chunks
2 salted duck eggs
1 cup rice flour
2 tablespoon flour
1 Tablespoon rice wine
Salt & pepper
2 tablespoon cornstarch
2 egg yolks

2 tablespoon butter
Handful of curry leaves
80ml evaporated milk, more if you like it saucy
2 cloves garlic, finely minced
2 chili padi, chopped

Steam or boil your salted duck eggs. Boiling should require around 15 minutes. After which seperate the yolks from the whites. Place in a bowl and mash till you get really tiny crumbs.

Marinade your chopped chicken with the rice wine, salt and black pepper and cornstarch. Leave in the fridge for at least  30 minutes. Meanwhile heat up your oil, break two yolks over the chicken and massage it in. Pour the flour mixture over and season with some more salt and black pepper. Really push the dry ingredients into the nooks of the bird. Deep-fry for about 10 minutes till crispy brown. Set aside in a basket to keep it crisp.

Now, in a wok, melt the 2 tablespoons of butter. On medium-high heat, fry the garlic, chili and curry leaves till fragrant. Add in your mashed up salted egg. Things will start to get foamy really fast, that's normal. Lower your heat to a medium-low. Once the yolks has started to cook, add in the evaporated milk and keep stirring to form a smooth sauce. You can add more evaporated milk if you desire more sauce. No one is judging. Toss your fried chicken through the sauce and you're ready.

Oh don't forget the fried egg as well.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #StayHomeWithAscott #BudgetTenDollars

caption:
Okay, let's talk buns. These pillowy ones start off with tangzhong starter, or a water roux starter. It's the byword nowadays for bread bakers aspiring towards elevated bread rolls and tender cinnamon buns. // Here's how a little bit of cooked starch makes a difference: By pre-cooking a % of the flour and liquid together, it pre-gelatinizes the starches in the flour meaning that the dough can absorb more water. With more water absorbed, the overall dough is less sticky and hence easier to work with. You could work more liquids into the dough - high hydration therefore equating to moister rolls that will stay fresh for longer.

Without further ado,

Perfect Burger Buns
Makes 8
Recipe from @domestic_gothess

Tangzhong:
20g bread flour
100ml water

Dough:
350g bread flour
7g dry yeast
1 TSP salt
50g caster sugar
1 tbsp milk powder (optional)
125ml milk
1 large egg
50g softened butter

Make the tangzhong first. In a small saucepan, combine the two ingredients and whisk over a medium flame till you get a paste consistency. Set aside to cool.

Place the flour, yeast, salt, sugar and milk powder in a mixing bowl. Whisk together. Fit your stand mixer with a dough hook and make a well in the center of your dry ingredients, add in the egg, milk and tangzhong. Mix until a dough is form. Making sure to scrap the bowl every now and then. Bit by bit, incorporate the softened butter bits. Keep mixing for at least 15 minutes. Scraping down constantly. You'll achieve a tender dough that peels away from the sides.

Transfer the dough to a lightly greased bowl and cling-film the top. Leave to rise until double in size. It will take about 1 hour in S'pore's weather.

Divide the dough into 8 pieces, ~ 90g/piece. Shape each dough to get a smooth ball. Spread them out across your lined baking tray. Leave to rise in a draft-free place for 1 hour. I recommend putting it in the oven and accompanying with a bowl of freshly boiled water for some steamy boosters.

Preheat the oven to 200°C (do make sure to remove your buns first). Egg wash them with beaten egg and milk before sprinkling on some sesame seeds.

Bake for 20 minutes.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen

caption:
#SihanSayDaBaoWhat Tang Shui edition // this #circuitbreaker, I admit to being somewhat of a Nazi when it comes to feeding my parents. No bread at home? I'm kneading a batch. Missing out on your laksa action? Nvm, I'm cooking it at home.

But there are several things that do not fall within my knowledge bracket and it's usually the more classic items that I do not have a penchant for in daily life... Till I had @TheChinesePotion 's No. 3 - a jovial mix of papaya, candied winter melon and White lotus seeds. It's pleasantly sweet, with the papaya possessing just the right amount of bite to compliment the knobs of White lotus seeds and goji Berry. I'm not one to understand the ins and outs of balancing one's Qi through your diet but one thing's for sure, you'll instantly feel rejuvenated after a bowlful of this. Definitely a much healthier option than reaching out for a handful of cookies.

Order now to enjoy $2 off their delivery fees.

caption:
Melty Cheese draped over drippy creamy eggs this morning on sriracha mayo loaded dream rolls from yesterday's baking experiment. B L I S S. A copy-cat of the iconic Fairfax #EggSlut sandwich except I forgot to layer on the caramelised onions which I had painstakingly gotten out of bed 30 minutes early to toil and tear over. Damm.

You can find the recipe on @timeoutlondon but I'm going to talk more about those eggs which begin in a cold pan.

First crack three eggs straight into a cold pan and throw in a big knob of butter. Don't stinge. Stir the eggs and butter together even before turning on the pilot light. "Almost till it forms like a sauce," says Alvin Cailan. Put the pan on medium heat and continue stirring with your spatula to create a velvety texture. Be sure to constantly scrape the bottoms of the pan and fold your eggs over to create loose layers. When the eggs start to bind, remove from the heat. These babies are ready. Sprinkle your chives over and spoon lovingly over your warmed buns. Yes, you know what I'm talking about...
~~~
#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #BudgetTenDollars #weaccidentallyaburger #eggporn

caption:

Excuse me as I make believe I'm in Korea just for a brief moment. Soju would be perfect right about now.

caption:
Disquieted by the unrest and chaos in other parts of the world, I take to baking to quell the anxiety.

Banana, date, pecan muffins it is and Carole Walter's recipe is a God-sent. If you've never tried this combination before, you are in for a treat.

Banana, date, pecan muffins
Makes 14

2 ripe bananas
1 3/4 cups flour
1/2 cup granulated sugar
1 TSP baking powder
1 TSP ground cardamom
1/2 TSP cinnamon
1/2 TSP salt
1/2 TSP baking soda

1/2 cup dates, pitted and chopped into bits
1/2 cup pecans, coarsely chopped
110g butter, melted and cooled to room temperature
1/2 cup dark brown sugar
1/2 cup plain yogurt
2 large eggs, beaten
1 TSP vanilla extract

Heat your oven to 190°C. Slice the bananas and proceed to mash them up to a pulp.

In a large bowl, whisk together all the dry ingredients. Chop your pecans and dates. Toss them through the dry ingredients and taking the time to seperate the pieces of dates with your fingertips.

In another bowl, whisk the butter and brown sugar together. Stir in the bananas, yogurt, eggs and vanilla.

Stir the banana-egg mixture into the dry ingredients. Making sure not to overmix. A few streaks of flour is fine. Using an ice cream scoop, ladle about 1/4 cup batter into each muffin tin.

Bake for 25 minutes.

Tip: if you don't have yogurt, just squeeze a quarter of a lemon into 1/2 cup of milk and leave to sit on the counter for half an hour.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #BudgetTenDollars #quarantinekitchen #StayHomeWithAscott

caption:
Old school Coffeeshop feels visited this morning with kopitiam eggs and kaya toast. ☕🥚. Splurged on these #CheonggyewonEgg (CGWE) eggs from Korean, because, why not enjoy life's better pleasures in their gold standard form when cooped up at home?

Reaping the benefits of #coldchainsystem, these eggs are incredibly fresh - hence, best demonstrated in kopitiam eggs. Who agrees?

I miss 'Killiney Kopitiam' Eggs
Makes a selfish portion of 2

2 eggs at room temp
500ml water
Soy sauce
White pepper

Bring 500ml of water to boil in a pot with a tight fitting lid. Once on a rolling boil, kill the heat and immediately add in a splash of water, 30ml, if you've a stickler for measurements.

Quickly lower the eggs in, gently, with a spoon. Then put the lid on and set the timer for 7 minutes. Remove the eggs from the water once the timer is up and place it in room temp water to stop the cooking.

Crack the eggs into saucers and slurp it up. Alternatively Kaya toast make the perfect dippers. ~~~
These CheonggyewonEgg, supported by Korea Agro-Fisheries & Food Trade Corp have just arrived on our shores and can be now purchased from Cold Storage! You'll have to look into the chiller section to find your loot. A tad more expensive than your usual eggs but well worth it if you're intending to work on those ramen eggs or onsen tamago. // To celebrate the launch, @brandfitsg is giving 100 lucky individuals 3 cartons of eggs each for FREE. Head on over their IG and comment on their most recent post for a chance to win.

#cheonggyewonegg #sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #koreaneggs #CGWE #sp

caption:
// Tonight is one for all the frills//
•••
Gyoza lace
Accommodates 6 - 8 gyozas

100ml of water
2 TSP of flour
1 two cornstarch

Pan-fry your gyoza as per usual. Till it's crisp and golden brown on the bottom. Whisk the flour and water mixture in the ratios as stated above. Rest your pan on a dry towel for about 5 seconds before pouring in the batter and putting over medium heat. You'll want to put the lid on immediately and let steam for 4 minutes.

Once that is done. Take the lid off and allow for the extra water to evaporate off. Trickle a little sesame oil off the sides of the pan to allow for easy release.

Once most of the water have vanished. Remove from heat. Allow to cool on an insulated surface for about 1 minute before flipping it out onto a plate, as you would a upside down cake, i.e. plate inverted over cake and then flipping the entire pan over. Et voilà ! 
#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #StayHomeWithAscott

caption:
猪脚卤蛋 Braised pig trotters and egg ~ a 70s kind of luxury dish that still hands out lashings of comfort and gravy, hip-hugging action these days. Some of you might shy away from eating the offals (sheesh, you don't know what you're missing out on) but the pig intestines in there are the best parts. Hand me a bowl of white rice and nobody gets hurt.

Braised Pig trotters and egg
Makes enough for 5.

1.5 kg of pork feet. About 1 feet chopped into 10 - 12 pieces.
3 tablespoon dark soy sauce
10 cloves garlic
Black pepper
2 cloves
2 cinnamon sticks
Ginger 6 inches, chopped into 6 bits.
5 Hard boiled eggs
300g Pig Intestines

Prep your pig intestines, you want them cleaned and chopped into 4cm segments.

In some oil, stir-fry your ginger and de-skinned garlic cloves till fragrant. Add in the pork feet, black pepper and dark soy sauce. Cooking till the skin is taut and most of the liquids have evaporated.

Pour in enough water to submerge the trotters. Bring to a boil, add in the intestines, dried spices and hard -boiled eggs. Leave to simmer for at least an hour on the lowest heat possible.

Season to taste and serve on a platter accompanied with bowls of steaming white rice.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #BudgetTenDollars #StayHomeWithAscott #food52 #pigtrotters

caption:
They say that "Cooking is about creating something delicious for someone else.". It's one thing to cook to pander to one's own cravings but to deal with your loved ones likes and dislikes... that's a different monster altogether.

My dad doesn't like chicken nor fatty pork, my little brother would plow through a whole bowl to excavate scallions and onions, my mother on the other hand is just a tough critique. If under usual circumstances, with this Hokkaido Pork Loin from @yakiniku_plaza, I would cook my favourite Katsudon and spam it with mirin soaked onions and chopped scallions overhead. Unfortunately, we had to settle for this tonkatsu-don which to be honest was elevated just merely by the pedigree of the pork. Lean yet tender simultaneously.

Meanwhile, let's talk Onsen Tamago ➡️ scroll right for evidence. I've just learnt that you can make these without a sous-vide machine just based on the laws of thermodynamics. Listen up.

Onsen Tamago
Makes 4 luscious eggs

In a pot, bring 1 litre of water to a rolling boil. Remove from heat and place on an insulated surface. Tip in 200 ml of room temperature water straight from the tap.

Using a spoon, gently roll in 4 eggs straight from the fridge into the water. Put the lid on and set the timer for 17 minutes.

Remove from water and leave on a plate for 5 minutes. Crack and enjoy.

Note that large eggs were used in this recipe. Results may vary for medium eggs. Recipe: @justonecookbook

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #food52 #onsentamago

caption:
#SihanSayDaBaoWhat Mon Night edition: @tamashii_sg Sakura Buta Ramen.

Just as some stellar pastas require little flourishes to stand out amongst the crowd, a front-runner of a ramen doesn't need to sweat the condiments - the togarashi powder, the dreaded sweet corn, pools of black garlic oil, the mad sprinkling of allium. Instead, Tamashii's take-home rendition of the Pork Ramen allows you to play it up any way you like.

I did nothing, one because I'm lazy af, two because the broth on its own was smack with umami, enriched with trickles of yolk from the jammy eggs. Why mess with perfection?

#savefnbsg #SGUnited #burpple #tamashiirobataya #sgjapanesefood #food52 #comfortfood

caption:
My hunger to experience nature's spring to summer runway collection has manifested in something green (with envy). 💚 Pandan Soft Milk Buns, the quintessential spring palette, and incredibly goregous to photograph too.

The recipe is up on @sulyntan 's profile and her recent #SoftMilkBunsClub movement has taken on a life of its own with netizen's scuttling in all directions, savoury with cheese and herbs, Milo chocolate filled buns and burger buns?!? It's a circus in there.

I followed the recipe to the tee except for the blending of 10 stalks of pandan leaves with the milk and sieving through for natural pandan flavoured milk. And stuffing each 54g of dough (made 9 buns instead of 16 which I baked in an 8" square tin) with 6g of Hainanese kaya. Second proofing was done in the cold depths of the fridge as I needed sleep and the thought of fresh bread in the morning was too alluring. Take it out of the fridge first thing in the morning and leave in a warm and draft-free place for about 40 minutes. Glaze with 1-egg + drizzle of milk 'egg-wash' and whack it in the 150°C oven. Would have done 50% coconut milk instead of milk but didn't have any to spare. All the more reason to revisit this recipe!

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #kayabun #BudgetTenDollars #StayHomeWithAscott

caption:
In the region of Brittany lies an island, Griox, a few kilometres of the main land. The 4.3km by 1.8km island enjoys a ultra mild micro-climate that draws in the tourists all year round. Once a major center of albacore tuna fishing, the island still boasts the livelihood of many skilled fishermen.

Groix & Nature (@groixetnature) is a boutique company that makes rillettes, cooked soups and dishes the traditional way. And trust you all know that I'm a big fan of fish rillette... But wait...their rillette range vary from Breton style scallop to whelk and even Mackerel with goat cheese. 🤯 My fall-back, the salmon rillette is unctous, punctuated with just the right amount of fat to plump up good ole' olive oil grilled toasts. Fun and immediate.

Available via @classicdelisg. Use [10DELI] to enjoy 10% off.

#ClassicDeliSG #sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #StayHomeWithAscott
comments: ['wonderfully simple yet 🙌', 'Yumm', 'What did you put below the rillettes?']

caption:
Don't be fooled by it's multi-components, 'oh-look-at-me, I'm so intimidating' appearance. {Ipoh Hor Fun} is actually very easy to put together for a huge party, in a methodical sense: prepare the soup base,  poach the chicken breast, fold some dumplings, cook off all the ingredients and it's done. But keep it to yourself -let others think you toiled for hours over this.

鸡丝虾河粉
Ingredients for 5

Broth
18 prawns - de-shelled, you just need the shell
Rock sugar
1 litre fish bone stock

15 IQF Frozen Tiger Prawns (from @tastegourmetmarket, use promo-code [SIHAN] to enjoy 5% off you entire cart)
Poached and Shredded chicken
Fried shallots
Greens
Sui Kow
Ipoh Hor Fun

Peel the prawns and reserve for dumpling-making. Fry the prawn heads and shells in oil till they turn red in colour. Add water and chicken parts and ikan bilis or prepared fish-bone stock. Simmer for at least an hour.

Strain the soup and transfer to a small pot.

Boil water in a wok and get ready a strainer. First put in your dumplings, these take a while to cook and don't do them in too large a batch to prevent them from sticking to one another. Blanch your Ipoh Hor Fun and leafy greens. Plate them up together with some shredded chicken (poached for 6 minutes in simmering broth/water and then switch off the heat and leave to continue cooking for another 15 mins) Cook your prawns in the boiling water for less than a minute.

Finally drench the hor fun with a few ladles of prawn broth and garnish the dish with fried shallots.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen

caption:
It's not a secret anymore. ::Burrata grilled cheese sandwich::. Things will never be the same again.

Tips: You'll want to lay the burrata on a paper towel first to soak up the extra water. Tear open your needed piece of Burrata to reveal the creamy innards before laying on the bread. Layer on some sliced cherry tomatoes and dried herbs. Then slap on some more burrata for good times. Making sure to season with pepper and salt along the way.

Also, mayo is your best friend if you want some legit grilled cheesus. That and low and slow. Can't hurry a princess can you? Anyway, Happy Sunday y'all.

#sskitchendisasters #fundamentallyflawedkitchen #grilledcheese #food52

caption:
Fitted in some extra kitchen time this afternoon after tackling lunch to roll out these Kueh Dadar. Took a little motivation but I rolled up my sleeves and got to work on these green scrolls in the end. Ah yes, green 💚, you don't see a lot of that on my feed. That's because nothing really photogenic comes out of it. Wait, actually scratch that: avocado on toast, matcha molten lava cake, green curry. Too soon to speak.

Back to the Kueh Dadar, these are self-indulgent affairs, worthy of brewing that most expensive pot of Oolong tea to accompany it with.

Kueh Dadar
Makes 8 rolls

200g plain flour
15 pandan leaves + 160ml water
200ml coconut milk (thick)
50ml water
1 egg
1 TSP oil
Pinch of salt

120g gula melaka
50ml water
5 pandan leaves knotted together
300g freshly grated coconut

Prepare the filling first. In a pot, place gula melaka, water and the knotted pandan leaves together. Heat up till the sugar completely dissolves and bubbles slightly. Pop in your grated coconut and stir to ensure that all the sugar syrup is absorbed and it is uniformly coloured a caramel brown. Set aside in a warm place.

Prepare the batter. Blitz the snipped up pandan leaves and water together till you get a slurry. Sieve that through a fine mesh sieve, making sure to press out all the remaining pandan juices. Combine the pandan juice with flour, salt, coconut milk, water, egg, oil and salt in a deep bowl. Whisk together to get a nice smooth green batter.

Heat up your pan. I used an 8 inch based pan. Dab the bottom thoroughly with oil. When the pan is about medium heat, pour in a ladle of batter and swirl slightly to get an even layer. Cook for about 2 minutes on one side before flipping over and finishing for another minute on the other.

Set on a wooden board, fill it nicely with just the right amount of coconut filling, and roll up nice and tight. Serve warm.

Send me some green lovin' 💚💚💚, if you're into this. 
#fundamentallyflawedkitchen #sskitchendisasters #food52 #StayHomeWithAscott

caption: So good to be able to eat out with the family! We had our Wagyu steaks at Bizen today. The Delmonico cut is very good! Delmonico is cut from the chuck and is basically the section just before it becomes the ribeye, so you get almost a ribeye but it’s cheaper since it is still considered a chuck steak. They have changed the sides since I wrote about them http://bit.ly/ieatBizen.  Now all the steaks come with two sides. The onion rings, corn, udon, rice were very good. The Wagyu cutlet and curry I can’t recommend.

caption:

With the gradual lifting of the CB, you can finally head down to experience the menu! Read my review and find out which is my favorite fish here: https://bit.ly/ieatbigifshsmallfish

Big Fish Small Fish is at 5 locations around Singapore:

caption:
Since it’s Father’s Day, the family agreed to make a trip to Sin Ming for prata. http://bit.ly/ieatAzizPrata. But as it turns out, phase 2 is still not the best time to eat at a coffeeshop! There were not enough tables available and the queue was super long! 
We ended up at the nearby Cafe Zeppin http://bit.ly/iEatSinMing which was still quiet as this is the first time they are opened on Sunday. They surprised me with a nice cup of cappuccino with a face on it (I think it’s supposed to be me!) with the words “Super Hero” on it. Nice touch! I would like to share it with all my fellow Father’s out there! Continue to be a Super Hero for your family! 
There wasn’t much of a choice for brunch so we ended up with their Lu  Rou fan and other small bites! Now that they are opened on Sunday, they will be rolling out a brunch menu in the coming weeks. It’s a cozy little cafe and we always wnjoy the hospitality of the lao ban niang (Phoebe) there! Just looking forward to simple things like French toast, bacon, sausage, eggs and pancakes! For lunch and dinner, the lu rou fan and seafood soup are very good. They import their own soy sauce from Taiwan for authenticity.

caption:
Here are the Special Father's Day sets from Peach Garden in case you are planning for something special this Sunday.  We have a special 10% discount promocode: <ieatishootipost10> for you if you order on 16 & 17 June here- https://bit.ly/ieatpeachgarden

I got to try all the dishes in both sets and they are very good, which can be expected of Peach Garden.  The highlights for me were the Chilli Crabs.  The crabs were large and solid and the chilli sauce was very well balanced without being too spicy.  It was the best Chilli Crabs I have had in recent memory.  The Braised Soon Hock with crispy pork was also excellent. The fish was substantial and the sauce was shiok.  I also liked both the Peking Duck and Crispy London Duck with dang gui sauce. The sets come with 5 main dishes and you also get to choose 3 complimentary items like a bottle of red wine, longevity buns, orh nee, Asparagus with Scallops etc.  They arrived in insulated red bags which was very impressive and one of the dishes also came in a claypot! 
Don't wait to the last minute to order.  They currently have FREE delivery island-wide. 
You may also call to order with the 10% promocode <ieatishootipost10> at any of their branches:

caption:
Very productive day in the kitchen today! I singlehandedly cooked Ayam Buah Keluak, Babi Assam and Prawn Sambal Bostador! 
How was I able to do this? The secret is that all the ingredients came ready packed as a DIY kit from Eurasian restaurant, Quentin’s. http://bit.ly/ieatQuentins

The buah keluak was already soaked and cracked opened! It really saved me the effort of going down to Tekka market a week ahead to buy and soak the buah keluak and then cracking them open one at a time. The sambal was already made and the lemongrass and shallots are sliced and portioned exactly! Even the chicken was already chopped to the right size! All I needed to do was the final step of putting everything together! 
All three dishes were well proportioned and the ingredients were good quality. I didn’t need to add anything else except a little sugar to balance out the sourness of the Assam and all three dishes were delicious! 
Do check out their cooking kits here! https://bit.ly/ieatquentinskits

Quentin’s is one of the last Eurasian restaurants around preserving our least understood  Heritage cuisine! So please support! @quentinssg 
#mediadrop

caption:
Lunch today is from our friends at Diamond Kitchen. I wrote about these passionate Gen Y Zi Charpreneurs a few years back. http://bit.ly/ieatdiamondkitchen. 
Their food is very good quality and they still go to buy the seafood from Jurong fishery port themselves 3 times a week to ensure freshness and quality.  They currently have a crab promo. 3x500g crabs cooked in any style for $49.90 which is about the price that I pay for crabs at the market! I tried several flavours and I like their black pepper the best. The crabs are quite solid. They are also having a promo on their whole seabass at $12.90 per fish. I also liked their beef hor fun which has the requisite wok hei. Their signature is their lala beehoon which has the sweetness of clam jus in it. It could have been better if the beehoon was more charred. Overall it was a very good meal! 
Check out their menu here: https://bit.ly/ieatdiamonmenu
WhatsApp: +65 96627600

caption:
Ever tried making Mee Pok Tar at home? I think many have tried making it like how the hawkers do it and have given up because it really is not practical to cook one bowl at a time for a family of five!

In this video, I show you how to make Mee Pok Tar for sharing just like how you would with spaghetti bolognese! To make it really authentic, I am using ingredients from Li Xin Teochew Fishball noodles whcih you can order directly from: https://bit.ly/ieatlixinnoodles

Their fishballs are made with pure yellowtail fish and has that texture that is very different from the fishballs you buy from the supermarket. Their her giao and fish rolls are still being made by hand. You can also order ready made pork lard and chilli which are very good quality and only $4 for a big tub. It really is cheaper than making myself! 
#sp @lixinfishball

caption: Been busy experimenting with new recipes. This is one that I am working on, a Flammenkeuche aka Tarte Flambee. Good for those who like thin and crispy pizza.  What toppings would you suggest?

caption: Our Hainanese pioneers really hit upon something special when they used crushed cream crackers to coat their pork chops. The crackers give an extra dimension of toasty flavour to the pork chops that make them really irresistible! We used pork collar instead of pork loin today and it really gave it a nice chewy and juicy bite! Here’s the recipe: http://bit.ly/ieatPorkChops. NB if you want to use the air fryer, you need to spray some oil to your crushed crackers and toast them slightly first before coating the pork. Then air fry or oven bake them. It will work as well!

caption:
My Pau quest continues! Today’s Pau come from Mdm Ling Bakery http://bit.ly/ieatMdmLing which is another place recommended by our readers. Those of you who love Tau Sar Pau would immediately recognize this style of Tau Sar Pau made famous by Forty Hands. Since they were introduced years back, these paus have been popping up in Singapore in various places. They are actually imported from JB and they are recognized by their distinctive flat disc shape and smooth tau sar. At 6 for $7.90, they actually cost more than our local variety but no one is complaining as they are less than half the price of the ones sold at the cafe!

I think they are nice but to be honest, these paus have never really blown me away. However, the skin is light and fluffy and their 8 hr slow cooked, de-hulled tau sar is smooth and not too sweet. I have always been prejudiced by their factory made look, but they do stand out as a tau sar pau which is easily recognizable. Sadly, our local tau sar pau are all pretty generic except for perhaps the ones at Joo Huat  http://bit.ly/ieatJooHuatPau who still make their own tau sar. Their Liu Sar paus are also quite nice, albeit also looking very factory made. The salted egg custard is runny and quite nice. 
They are available online and Mdm Ling Bakery also import cookies from Malaysia which you might like to check out at their website.

#mediadrop

caption: So good to be able to eat out with the family! We had our Wagyu steaks at Bizen today. The Delmonico cut is very good! Delmonico is cut from the chuck and is basically the section just before it becomes the ribeye, so you get almost a ribeye but it’s cheaper since it is still considered a chuck steak. They have changed the sides since I wrote about them http://bit.ly/ieatBizen.  Now all the steaks come with two sides. The onion rings, corn, udon, rice were very good. The Wagyu cutlet and curry I can’t recommend.

caption:
Since it’s Father’s Day, the family agreed to make a trip to Sin Ming for prata. http://bit.ly/ieatAzizPrata. But as it turns out, phase 2 is still not the best time to eat at a coffeeshop! There were not enough tables available and the queue was super long! 
We ended up at the nearby Cafe Zeppin http://bit.ly/iEatSinMing which was still quiet as this is the first time they are opened on Sunday. They surprised me with a nice cup of cappuccino with a face on it (I think it’s supposed to be me!) with the words “Super Hero” on it. Nice touch! I would like to share it with all my fellow Father’s out there! Continue to be a Super Hero for your family! 
There wasn’t much of a choice for brunch so we ended up with their Lu  Rou fan and other small bites! Now that they are opened on Sunday, they will be rolling out a brunch menu in the coming weeks. It’s a cozy little cafe and we always wnjoy the hospitality of the lao ban niang (Phoebe) there! Just looking forward to simple things like French toast, bacon, sausage, eggs and pancakes! For lunch and dinner, the lu rou fan and seafood soup are very good. They import their own soy sauce from Taiwan for authenticity.

caption:
Here are the Special Father's Day sets from Peach Garden in case you are planning for something special this Sunday.  We have a special 10% discount promocode: <ieatishootipost10> for you if you order on 16 & 17 June here- https://bit.ly/ieatpeachgarden

I got to try all the dishes in both sets and they are very good, which can be expected of Peach Garden.  The highlights for me were the Chilli Crabs.  The crabs were large and solid and the chilli sauce was very well balanced without being too spicy.  It was the best Chilli Crabs I have had in recent memory.  The Braised Soon Hock with crispy pork was also excellent. The fish was substantial and the sauce was shiok.  I also liked both the Peking Duck and Crispy London Duck with dang gui sauce. The sets come with 5 main dishes and you also get to choose 3 complimentary items like a bottle of red wine, longevity buns, orh nee, Asparagus with Scallops etc.  They arrived in insulated red bags which was very impressive and one of the dishes also came in a claypot! 
Don't wait to the last minute to order.  They currently have FREE delivery island-wide. 
You may also call to order with the 10% promocode <ieatishootipost10> at any of their branches:
PG @ OCBC Centre: 6535 7833
PG @ Thomson Plaza: 6451 3233
PG @ Hotel Miramar: 6736 3833
PG @ The Metropolis: 6334 7833
PG @ Chinatown Point: 6702 0603

Remember that the promocode is valid on 16 & 17 June only so mai tu liao!
#sp @peachgardensg

caption:
Very productive day in the kitchen today! I singlehandedly cooked Ayam Buah Keluak, Babi Assam and Prawn Sambal Bostador! 
How was I able to do this? The secret is that all the ingredients came ready packed as a DIY kit from Eurasian restaurant, Quentin’s. http://bit.ly/ieatQuentins

The buah keluak was already soaked and cracked opened! It really saved me the effort of going down to Tekka market a week ahead to buy and soak the buah keluak and then cracking them open one at a time. The sambal was already made and the lemongrass and shallots are sliced and portioned exactly! Even the chicken was already chopped to the right size! All I needed to do was the final step of putting everything together! 
All three dishes were well proportioned and the ingredients were good quality. I didn’t need to add anything else except a little sugar to balance out the sourness of the Assam and all three dishes were delicious! 
Do check out their cooking kits here! https://bit.ly/ieatquentinskits

Quentin’s is one of the last Eurasian restaurants around preserving our least understood  Heritage cuisine! So please support! @quentinssg 
#mediadrop

caption:
Lunch today is from our friends at Diamond Kitchen. I wrote about these passionate Gen Y Zi Charpreneurs a few years back. http://bit.ly/ieatdiamondkitchen. 
Their food is very good quality and they still go to buy the seafood from Jurong fishery port themselves 3 times a week to ensure freshness and quality.  They currently have a crab promo. 3x500g crabs cooked in any style for $49.90 which is about the price that I pay for crabs at the market! I tried several flavours and I like their black pepper the best. The crabs are quite solid. They are also having a promo on their whole seabass at $12.90 per fish. I also liked their beef hor fun which has the requisite wok hei. Their signature is their lala beehoon which has the sweetness of clam jus in it. It could have been better if the beehoon was more charred. Overall it was a very good meal! 
Check out their menu here: https://bit.ly/ieatdiamonmenu
WhatsApp: +65 96627600

#mediadrop

caption:
Ever tried making Mee Pok Tar at home? I think many have tried making it like how the hawkers do it and have given up because it really is not practical to cook one bowl at a time for a family of five!

In this video, I show you how to make Mee Pok Tar for sharing just like how you would with spaghetti bolognese! To make it really authentic, I am using ingredients from Li Xin Teochew Fishball noodles whcih you can order directly from: https://bit.ly/ieatlixinnoodles

Their fishballs are made with pure yellowtail fish and has that texture that is very different from the fishballs you buy from the supermarket. Their her giao and fish rolls are still being made by hand. You can also order ready made pork lard and chilli which are very good quality and only $4 for a big tub. It really is cheaper than making myself! 
#sp @lixinfishball

caption: Been busy experimenting with new recipes. This is one that I am working on, a Flammenkeuche aka Tarte Flambee. It’s a crispy thin “pizza” from the Alsace region of France which borders Germany. In Germany it’s called a Flammkuchen. It’s very versatile and you can top it with almost anything you like. Good for those who like thin and crispy pizza.  What toppings would you suggest?

caption: Our Hainanese pioneers really hit upon something special when they used crushed cream crackers to coat their pork chops. The crackers give an extra dimension of toasty flavour to the pork chops that make them really irresistible! We used pork collar instead of pork loin today and it really gave it a nice chewy and juicy bite! Here’s the recipe: http://bit.ly/ieatPorkChops. NB if you want to use the air fryer, you need to spray some oil to your crushed crackers and toast them slightly first before coating the pork. Then air fry or oven bake them. It will work as well!

caption:
My Pau quest continues! Today’s Pau come from Mdm Ling Bakery http://bit.ly/ieatMdmLing which is another place recommended by our readers. Those of you who love Tau Sar Pau would immediately recognize this style of Tau Sar Pau made famous by Forty Hands. Since they were introduced years back, these paus have been popping up in Singapore in various places. They are actually imported from JB and they are recognized by their distinctive flat disc shape and smooth tau sar. At 6 for $7.90, they actually cost more than our local variety but no one is complaining as they are less than half the price of the ones sold at the cafe!

I think they are nice but to be honest, these paus have never really blown me away. However, the skin is light and fluffy and their 8 hr slow cooked, de-hulled tau sar is smooth and not too sweet. I have always been prejudiced by their factory made look, but they do stand out as a tau sar pau which is easily recognizable. Sadly, our local tau sar pau are all pretty generic except for perhaps the ones at Joo Huat  http://bit.ly/ieatJooHuatPau who still make their own tau sar. Their Liu Sar paus are also quite nice, albeit also looking very factory made. The salted egg custard is runny and quite nice. 
They are available online and Mdm Ling Bakery also import cookies from Malaysia which you might like to check out at their website.

#mediadrop

caption:
Who else loves to eat Pau? Over the years, the bad news is that the quality of our paus seem to be on the decline. I used to like Teck Kee but they are gone. But even before they closed, the quality was already quite bad: http://bit.ly/ieatTeckKeePau. Tiong Bahru Pau used to be really good http://bit.ly/ieattiongbahrupau, but quality has also declined over the years. Thankfully Tanjong Rhu Pau is still good, though I find the skin is not as tender and as thin as before. The little charsiu paus are very good and has that requisite charcoal flavour. http://bit.ly/ieattanjongrhupau. 
Are there any places you can recommend for a really good big Pau?  I am hoping someone would bring our Pau to the next level and help arrest the decline.

caption:
Had an amazing lunch today from Michelin Star Chef Han Li Guang of Labyrinth. They have just launched Miss Vanda which is their online platform for their takeaway menu. The food is prepared at their kitchen at Labyrinth by the same culinary team.  The two outstanding dishes today were the Wagyu Rendang Buah Keluak which uses Wagyu intercostals braised till fork tender and cooked in a mild rendang gravy and bua keluak purée. It is the best thing that has been delivered to our doorstep since CB started. Their laksa is also really good. Definitely a notch above the hawker version. It’s chock full of seafood like prawns, scallop dumplings  and mussels and the gravy is full of dried prawns, aromatic rempah, laksa leaves and freshly squeezed coconut. The har cheong gai would have been excellent fresh but they were already soft when they arrived, but the surprise was that they have been deboned, so it was really easy to eat. The chicken rice was the only dish I felt ambivalent about. Don’t compare it with the local version as it is supposed to be a claypot “ANG MOH” version that his grandma used to make which comes with a creamy mushroom sauce that tasted a bit like Chicken Ala King. 
Overall, the quality of the food is very good. The team are doing a great job making ultimate versions of our local dishes. Yes, they are more expensive than the hawker version but it wouldn’t be fair to compare their pricing with the hawkers. Instead, you should compare the laksa with a plate of pasta then you will be able to see it’s true value! 
You can order their dishes from http://bit.ly/ieatMsVanda

caption:
Had a sudden hankering for Wantons today! I am referring to the local version which is filled with small,  bite sized minced pork — the type they serve with wanton mee. After boiling, I just toss them in a bit of shallot oil to prevent sticking, and a dash of light soy sauce. Bit like eating ravioli! It’s really a meal by itself! 
I have been toying with the perfect wanton recipe (the local type, not the HK type) for a while now. The filling has to be mainly pork with a flavour you just have to keep eating. Today I seasoned the pork with fried white pepper and salt, fried sole fish powder, oil, Chinese wine, cornflour and water. For a better bite, I added extra diced pork fat. Quite close, but can still improve. Water chestnut is not in the recipe as I feel it will turn it into a sui gao instead. Any other suggestions are most welcome!

caption:
Here's a recipe that is perfect for those of you who are beginner cooks! It's inspired by the scrambled egg sandwich that is so popular in Hong Kong! Unlike the Western style scrambled eggs, this method results in layers of tender, velvety and really yummy eggs which is just perfect in a sandwich with luncheon meat and a cup of kopi/tea! Recipe here: bit.ly/ieatScrambleEggs

If you haven't started cooking yet, what are you waiting for? All you need is two eggs, butter, salt and a pan. You can even omit the cornflour slurry if you don't have it handy!

Which brand of luncheon meat would you recommend?

It is so convenient it is to have fish soup noodle / vegetables at home without much prepartion. All items are pre-slice and pre-wash, thus it saves you lot of prep time. Plus you can even enjoy authentic Japanese charcoal-grilled teriyaki sticks in mins just by heating.

Don’t forget to also grab brown rice-fed chicken from @benjachickensingapore. This is the preferred chicken used in michelin star restaurants in Thailand. They are raised without hormones and antibiotics, and are tender and more juicy. It is available in chicken griller (whole chicken), skinless boneless breast, skinless boneless leg, and skin-on boneless leg.

Free delivery for purchases above $65. Plus, we will be giving away FREE Kitchen Joy Burger Set with a minimum spending of $75. It is going to be exciting! See you this Friday 8.30pm!

Over the past few months, burnt cheesecake has become the darling of our local dessert scene. You see them in a lot of restaurants. Now, sister duo @fiftygramss has perfected their Basque burnt cheesecake recipe and are selling it online! ⁣
⁣
Their burnt cheesecake features a beautifully caramelized brûléed crust. It adds a mysterious, but highly enjoyable, flavour akin to salted caramel. I cut a slice for myself, savouring it from the burnt crust, to the velvety smooth centre. As compared to many other cheesecakes I have tried, their version is a lot richer and gloriously cheesier! ⁣
⁣
It can be eaten immediately (if you desire that lava effect) or you can store it in the fridge for two hours before diving into it. You can also pair it with a dollop of cream. Too easy to love! Whatsapp 9711 3198 to order.

caption: I have eaten Mapo Tofu, I have eaten Lion’s Head Meatball. But what if we combine both and eat together? Tonight, we are enjoying takeaway from @restaurantibid. Inspired by food anime Yukihira Soma of Shokugeki No Soma @foodwarsofficial, MasterChef Asia winner @woowaileong has interestingly combined Ibid-style Mapo Tofu with Lion’s Head Meatball and Scallion Oil Noodles. It’s weird initially but somehow, it’s tasty 😆 We paired it with Boneless Chicken Wings stuffed with Fish Mousse and Foie Gras, Cheese ShaoPing, Lao Gan Ma Coleslaw, Shaoxing Creamed Spinach ans Potato Puree. You must grab their Chocolate Chip and Walnut Cookies. That seductive brown butter and chocolate notes is great for a perk-me-up! They are still doing delivery this week, whatsapp 91518698 to order!

caption:
Treat your dad to a wholesome and hearty meal from @alpinespringcatering this Father’s Day! Suitable for 5-7pax, the halal mini buffet has 7 different courses for you to choose from. ⁣⁣
⁣
We were really impressed with the Emperor Herbal Chicken. Expect a whole tender chicken slow-cooked in a heady broth with herbs such as angelica root,wolfberries and lovage rhizome. There is no better party fish than the Homemade Thai Style Mango Fish. The sweet and sour sauce pairs perfectly with the fried fish.⁣
⁣
Seafood lovers should not miss their Imperial Seafood Pot that’s packed with savory and briny flavours from Hokkaido Scallops, Sea Cucumber, Tiger Prawns and Sliced Fish. We also had White Pepper Clams and Seafood Beancurd Roll in Chilli Crab sauce.⁣
⁣
Call 6570 9888 or visit https://www.alpinespring.sg/ to order now!

caption:
[ FREE 16 HEAD ABALONE WHEN YOU ORDER FATHER’S DAY MENU ] The best gift you can give Dad on Father's Day is a full stomach. Whether he's a meat guy, or more of a seafood fan, @onandondiners Father’s Day Mini Buffet Set will be perfect for him. Suitable for 5-7pax, the buffet has 7 different courses for you to choose from. ⁣
⁣
Some of my favourites include the Imperial Seafood Pot that’s packed with savory and briny flavours from Hokkaido Scallops, Sea Cucumber, Tiger Prawns and Sliced Fish. The succulent Teochew Style Braised Duck which comes with a thick braising sauce is very tasty. I have many servings of rice whenever I order their Nonya Pineapple Assam Fish. We also love the Golden Otah Kong Ba Pau and Chinese Spinach with Trio of Egg. ⁣
⁣
Receive a FREE Can of On & On Diner’s 16 head Abalone if you order their Father’s Day menu by this Wednesday (17 June). Call 6570 9939 or visit https://www.onandon.sg to order now!

caption:
Run by two sisters who are Eastern Malaysian, 林玉梅 Lin Yu Mei Kolo Mee serves two dishes: Kolo Mee ($4/small & $5/large) & Sarawak Laksa ($6). The kolo mee here really evoked nostalgia. The fragrant lard oil used makes the bowl of noodles incredibly aromatic.

Address: 14 Haig Road, Haig Road Market & Food Centre, #01-33 Singapore 430014

caption:
We had a feast from @shaoparadise, a hawker stall in Amoy Street Food Centre run by a 70-year-old uncle. Despite being an amputee and having gone through bypass surgery, he still goes to the stall daily to cook. The tender steamed chicken comes dressed with sesame oil, and goes well with its bowl of chicken rice. Beyond that, the chilli sauce also packs a tangy punch. No doubt, this is the thing that makes the chicken rice meal. ⁣
⁣
Anything with their signature Thai chilli sauce is a must-order. We had the Thai tofu and Thai style gizzard. It is sweet, savory, tangy and spicy, the thick consistency makes this sauce the perfect compliment. Honestly, I was asking if they can bottle up this sauce. ⁣
⁣
Don’t forget to pair your meal with their shrimp dumpling soup. Wrapped with fresh shrimp, minced meat and crunchy water chestnut, the plump dumpling was packed generously with ingredients and every bite made me crave another. ⁣
⁣
I had multiple servings of their Black Vinegar Pig Trotters. The tender, gelatinous pork trotters is beautifully simmered in the aromatic yet pungent sweet and sour black vinegar.⁣
⁣
Bentos are available as well. Islandwide delivery available. Whatsapp 97697868⁣ to order! ⁣

caption:

Their flaky and buttery Butter Croissant had a nice crisp and soft core. The pastry was slightly sweet, with a touch of saltiness coming through as well. caption:
Dinner last night was from @missvandasg, the delivery arm of @restaurantlabyrinth. I was pretty excited because @han_lg is always reinterpreting traditions. ⁣
⁣
One of the offerings on Miss Vanda is the Labyrinth signature “Ang Moh” Chicken Rice. Chef Han’s grandma used to work as landlady and housekeeper cooking for a British family. Hence, this is her version of the quintessential Hainanese Chicken Rice. The aromatic chicken rice is served with juicy free range Kampong chicken and creamy chicken and mushroom sauce, complete with the nicely charred crispy rice bits. This is like the Singaporean risotto. ⁣
⁣
We love the Wagyu Buah Keluak Rendang. They slow braised it overnight, hence it is so tender. And the flavours are enriched with buah keluak, which is known as Asia’s truffle.⁣
⁣
Their Seafood Laksa is super rich and creamy. It is served with grilled Argentinian red prawns,  local green lip mussels, homemade fish paste and crabmeat dumplings. We also had the boneless Crispy Har Cheong Chicken Wings and Hainanese Style Sweet and Sour Sakura Pork Tomahawk.⁣
⁣
Don’t forget to get a bottle of Hainanese Kaya for breakfast the next day. It is made with fresh coconut milk, local organic free range eggs and young pandan leaves, gently stirred for over 2-3 hours. ⁣
⁣
Minimum spending is $50. They are open 7 days a week and they do islandwide delivery at $10 flat fee no matter where you stay or work. Self pick is also available, at Esplanade Mall 02-23. ⁣
⁣
Order from www.missvanda.sg today!

caption:
Today, we’re trying out a crowd-favourite recipe that we found on @shermainexk Instagram post. It’s easy, flaky, and super addictive - this Easy Air Fryer Egg Tarts recipe will have you lining your Tupperware with egg custard pastries for days.
.
I used brown sugar instead of regular white sugar, and the resulting egg tarts had a good amount of caramel smokiness to them. Using frozen prata to replace the typical shortcrust tart shell is certainly a stroke of genius, because it reduces the preparation time by a lot.
.
This recipe makes egg tarts that are closer in taste and texture to Portuguese egg tarts, with a flaky, crispy crust and smooth, egg custard centre. If you have an air fryer at home, pick up a pack of frozen prata from the supermarket and try out this simple recipe. Share your experience with us! ~ @colourmeamused

caption:
Hidden away at Forum Galleria Orchard Road, @brownbutter.sg sits comfortably between its cousin restaurants, Hana Japanese Restaurant and The Benjamin Browns. Of course, I had to try Brown Butter’s insta-famous desserts. Shaped cheekily like a cartoon block of cheese, I loved the attention to detail with the little holes on the Lemon Cheesecake.
.
Priced at S$8.90+, I felt that it was a little exorbitant for a small slice of cake. The difference between these cakes and other cheesecakes is easily spotted.
.
Instead of having a crunchy biscuit base attached to the cake, these cakes came without a base and sat atop biscuits crumbs scattered in an artfully careless manner. Have you tried the desserts at Brown Butter Cafe yet? ~ @stercei

caption:
[CLOSED] Here’s a little something to spice up your life. @kebabsfaktory  brings us an all-new flavour: Mala Kebabs. From 29 June 2020, you can turn any kebab into a sizzling hot mala kebab.
.
The Mala Lamb Shawarma was exceptionally fiery – together with the juicy, gamey lamb meat, the tongue-tingling mala spices made me break out in a sweat. You can also get these mala flavours in their Signature Rolls, Salads and Rice Boxes.
.
And for 5 lucky winners, we’ll be giving away S$20 vouchers so that you can enjoy this all-new mala sensation for yourself!
****
Here’s how to win: 
1. Like our post.
2. Follow @sethluicious and @kebabsfaktory 
3. Comment why you’d like to win the vouchers.
4. Tag a friend!
****
Giveaway ends at 11.59pm on 1 July 2020. Winner will be announced the following day (2 July 2020) at 11am. Stay tuned to see if you have won. All the best!

Feeling in need of something comforting and soothing? Warm yourself up with a piping bowl of frog leg porridge!
.
Fight off the gloom with the sizzling fragrance of tender frog legs immersed in silky, warm porridge. Apart from their immensely comforting congee, @g7liveseafood offers seafood delights and a myriad of zi char dishes.
.
The Marmite Pork Ribs also deserves a mention; crispy ribs coated in a thick sticky, sweet and savoury glaze make this side dish an unbeatable choice. ~ @jermtard

caption:
I think you have to agree that there is nothing better than ice cream. Rain or shine, a pint of ice cream is always welcome.
.
This effortless 3-ingredient recipe promises ice cream that's just as good as what you get in the store. I was pretty impressed with how thick, creamy and rich this ice cream turned out - and all without an ice cream maker.
.
Not to mention, the speculoos with its caramel notes was just the icing on the cake - a dream for all the sweet tooths out there. This recipe is so simple and customisable that you can make essentially make any flavour you like.
.
The world is your ice cream flavour, so try this recipe out and tell us what you would make your ice cream with! ~ @bunny2302

caption:
Nestled under a block of flats in the quiet estate of Pandan Gardens is @ahhuateochewnoodle.
.
Helmed by a father-daughter team, this is unlike your usual Teochew fishball noodles. Their speciality Homemade Fuzhou Fishball With Rice Needle Noodles (S$3) might be a tad monochromatic but packs huge flavour.
.
Served with rice needle noodles (more commonly known as lao shu fen), a medley of springy fishballs, prized herh kiao and a couple of Ah Hua Teochew Fishball Noodle unique creations, I was slurping every last bit of these noodles.
.
Though not located in the most accessible place, I have to say that Ah Hua Teochew Fishball Noodle will make it worth your while. ~@bunny2302

caption:
When staying at home for an extended period of time gets you down, I'm sure you're like me and seek comfort in food. @thecommunalplace Pancake Tower (S$16) will put a smile on your face instantly with its three-layered fluffy goodness that comes with maple syrup and a generous scattering of cookie crumbles, blueberries, and strawberries.
.
They are thick, and airy, with just the right amount of sweetness, so you won't feel the need to drizzle too much maple syrup just to enjoy it! If you haven't tried them yet, order today with their islandwide delivery service and current 2-for-1 promotion. ~ @waniology

caption:
Beo Crescent Hainanese Curry Rice puts all other Hainanese curry rice stalls to shame. A luscious and satisfying curry that's messily ladled over a plate of rice, this hits the spot alright. It's a little thinner than most curry dishes but twice as good.
.
Another item that you have to get on your plate is Beo Crescent Hainanese Curry Rice's Crispy Pork. These moreish rashers are crispy to a fault and dangerously addictive, providing a delightful savoury crunch to pair with your rice.
.
Besides the Crispy Pork, Beo Crescent Hainanese Curry also has fantastic meat and vegetable selections that are just as good! At an affordable price point, No Name Hainanese Curry Rice surely lives up to its name, or lack thereof. ~@ bunny2302

caption:
Dalgona coffee is a bonafide hit of 2020; even more so with its fluffy and velvety smooth texture. This time, we'll be taking things up a notch. Inspired by the viral drink, we have made a no-churn version of Dalgona-inspired Ice Cream loaded with delicious toffee bits. .
A memorable treat you won't soon forget, this combination is a match made in heaven. Rich, creamy and decadent, the ice cream melts in your mouth with mellow sweetness and a deep coffee flavour.
.
Coupled with a hint of caramel crunchiness from the toffee bits, I'm sure this dessert will "mocha" you crazy! ~ @jermtard

caption:
In the Whampoa Makan Place, there's a gem that is replete with history. @matasohsg dates back to the 1950s, where hawker life was as rustic as it gets.
.
With handmade fishball and meatballs that are made with 100% yellowtail fish, that makes all the difference, trust me. Their Soh Special (S$4.50/S$5.50) is worth the trip down. A wobbly onsen egg, al dente noodles coupled with those springy and bouncy fishballs - it's a perfect meal if I do say so myself. Make the trip down to Whampoa Makan Place and try it out for yourself! ~@bunny2302

caption:
Impress your friends and family with one of @bobthebakerboy’s out-of-the-box cake designs, like this Defying Gravity Floating Beer Can Cake (from S$138). You can add on tiers, change the colour and the brand as well as the flavour of the cake itself, according to your fancy. But most importantly, it’s one of the best-tasting cakes I’ve had in a long time!
.
This one was made with Belgian Chocolate and the layers were moist and soft, without overwhelming the tastebuds. Their cakes are also made with lower sugar, so it’s healthier than your regular store-bought cake. Take it from me, as someone who can’t get enough of cake; this one is a treat you’ll want to take your time to savour! #sp ~@waniology

caption:
@lovehandleburgers isn't just any vegan burger spot; their burgers start from only S$10 and are packed with bold flavours - not something you'd expect from a vegan place.
.
Their Double Cheeseburger (S$17) consists of two layers of Impossible™ patties, two slices of melted vegan cheese, caramelised onions, burger sauce, and pickles. The homemade brioche buns remained exceptionally firm, despite the journey during delivery.
.
Sink your teeth into one of the creations now, as they're available for islandwide delivery with only a S$10 delivery fee! Note that there's S$30 minimum spending. ~ @waniology

caption:
For most of us working professionals, a cup of coffee is never far from our caffeine-dependent hands. As a coffee fiend who can’t do without my daily cuppa, I was delighted to takethe Bootstrap Mix Pack (S$35) from @bootstrapcoldbrewsg for a spin.
.
My favourite drink from the pack had to be the Bootstrap Cold Brew Milk & Manuka Honey. The manuka honey brought out the velvety smooth sweetness in the coffee and milk, and smoothed over most of the bitter edge from the coffee.
.
This is a classic white coffee, but with a twist. Bootstrap Beverages’ signature cold brew comes with creamy 100% fresh milk, and the floral sweetness of organic New Zealand manuka honey - it has natural healing properties!
.
Coffee or tea, Bootstrap Beverages’ cold brewing technique certainly brings out the best in the beans and leaves. Ready for an awesome perk-me-up? #sp ~ @colourmeamused

caption:
In the gleaming white-washed walls of Maxwell Chambers sits @dumplings.ru , a Russian restaurant serving authentic Russian delights that are sure to charm you.
.
Well, if you are a little nervous about diving headfirst into the depth of Russian cuisine don't worry, these colourful dumplings are a wonderful introduction. With robust and tasty filling such as beef, lamb and even potato and bacon, these are simply scrumptious.
.
Perfect for lunch and dinner, you can even dip your toes and order a Ukrainian Borscht (S$8.50) while you're at it. Fusion Dumplings puts on no airs and trust me, you'll find yourself liking Russian food before you know it! ~ @bunny2302

caption:
Out of eggs? You can still make a chocolatey dessert, with this Mayonnaise Chocolate Cake recipe. The thought of putting savoury mayonnaise in sweet chocolate cake might seem really gross to most, but I gave it a try to see how it turns out.
.
This cake is much fluffier, with a decent crumb pattern that made it like a chocolatey sponge cake. It’s a little stickier on the bottom, almost like sticky date pudding.
.
The baking does yield a rather large cake, but you can’t ever have too much chocolate cake, after all. Share the love with your family and friends - and maybe only reveal the secret ingredient to them after they’ve showered you with praises for your baking prowess.
.
If you’re intrigued by this recipe, why not give it a try? Let us know if this strange ingredient substitution works for you too. ~ @colourmeamused

caption:
If you like zi char, then you've probably heard about @kengengkee. A household name, you'll know you're in for a good time when you order from KEK Seafood, so I ordered their Family Set D (S$116) that's good for four to six people.
.
The highlight of the set has to be their signature Moonlight Hor Fun that came with moon-like egg yolks intact when delivered, poised in the middle of the fried noodles. Break the egg and you'll get hor fun covered in a velvety, silky sauce with moreish, fatty slices of lap cheong and lard.
.
Other dishes I would recommend would be the Coffee Ribs and the Salted Egg Prawns. Moreover, KEK Seafood is so generous with their portions you'll have yummy leftovers for days. Order up a feast from KEK Seafood and trust me you won't be disappointed! ~ @bunny2302

caption:
For those with a sweet tooth and can’t resist desserts, you’ve probably been spending your time baking, and indulging in your bakes. Banana bread, sourdough and cookies aside, sometimes you want to treat yourself to something that’s a little more decadent.
.
Try out this recipe for @milosingapore Bread “Tiramisu” that you can make in just 30 minutes!
.
Be generous with the Milo powder, because who doesn’t love that chocolatey, malty goodness? Bonus: adding Milo powder on top creates a brittle, sweet layer. I’d recommend chilling the “tiramisu” in the fridge overnight, to give it a bit more structure. Plus, the soft, chewy texture is more palatable when chilled.
.
If you’re giving this a try, let us know how it goes! What other recipes would you like to see us try? ~ @colourmeamused

caption:
Our favourite @mcdsg may have finally returned to us after a brief hiatus, but some things money still can’t buy. Yes, I’m talking about the seasonal and very much beloved Prosperity Burger from McDonald’s. Well, to save us the heartache of pining for this seasonal burger, here’s a recipe for DIY McDonald’s Prosperity Burger, in just 30 minutes!
.
While the sliced onions are added raw, like how McDonald’s does it, feel free to grill the onions very lightly if that’s your preference. Personally, I find the sharp, pungent bite from raw sliced onions provides an additional dimension to the burger.
.
The sauce was surprisingly close to McDonald’s rendition, albeit a tad saltier and thicker in consistency. Try it out, and let us know if there’s anything you’d change about the recipe! ~ @colourmeamused

caption:
I’m sure we’ve all been ordering more food delivery during this #StayHome period. I know I certainly have – when the food cravings hit, out comes my mobile phone and off I go onto a food delivery app.
.
I have to admit, it’s frustrating when you’re ‘hangry’ and the network connection somehow chooses that moment to glitch. All the dim sum items you’ve added into your cart? Deleted, and now you have to start over again.
.
Even if we don’t order delivery as much since dine-in is available from 19 June onwards, working from home has made me realise how much we rely on fast network connections –and how frustrating it is when glitches happen, like our trippy glitched post yesterday.
.
If you’re tired of slow network connections glitching up your life, #ditchyourglitch and try the #gigaexperience.
.
@gigaexperience's newest, best plan weighs in at 40GB for S$20 with no contract (price reverts to 40GB for S$30 after 12 months). You can rollover your data, so there’s no wastage of unused data! And if you use up your data, simply purchase a data pack – no hidden fees here. Free rollover data, 24/7 support and no hidden fees– say goodbye to glitches, ‘hangry’ outbursts, and hello to Singapore’s fastest network. #sp #giga ~ @colourmeamused

caption:
Those of us who enjoy Asian desserts would be used to sweet potatoes. From sweet potato sesame balls, to bubur cha cha, these starchy roots add lots of chewy bite to our favourite sweet treats.
.
Let’s explore a different side of desserts and sweet treats, with Anthony Bourdain’s Candied Sweet Potatoes with Bourbon.
.
Together with the bourbon sauce, it was an absolute delight. The butter and sugar in the sauce left a creamy mouthfeel, while a hint of tartness from the apple cider played on my palate. The alcohol content from the bourbon and cider would’ve burnt off during the cooking process, so all that’s left of the bourbon was mostly deep notes of caramel, vanilla and molasses.
.
Try it, and let us know how it goes! ~ @colourmemamused

caption:
Weighing 170g each, these Copycat @levainbakery Chocolate Chip Walnut Cookies can be a hefty snack!
.
Just like the real deal, the cookies were perfectly crunchy on the outside, yet soft, chewy, and gooey inside.
.
You definitely have to curb that cookie monster in you to avoid overeating these giant cookies! ~ @fel_z

caption:
Some days you don’t want fancy burgers going for S$15 a pop. You just want a no-frills, down-to-earth burger. Patty, bun, condiments; the three most important aspects that make or break a burger.

Craving cheap but good burgers, I was delighted to discover @zippbnp, located at Amoy Street Food Centre.

Starting off strong with the Hamburger (S$5.70/single patty, S$8.70/double patty), this was a burger that I couldn’t wait to sink my teeth into. Even though I got the single patty burger, the 150g handmade patty was already so thick that it took a little effort to fit in my mouth---I can hardly imagine what the double patty would be like!

Zipp Burger & Pasta is truly one of those hidden gems, but now that the cat’s out of the bag, you’ll know where you can get excellent, scrumptious burgers. What’s your go-to spot for burgers? ~ @colourmeamused

caption: Fragrant and fluffy steamed nasi dagang aside, first-timers trying @yes.nasi.kukus should not miss their Signature Fried Chicken (S$4, a la carte order). Juicy and succulent, every inch of the chicken thigh was deep-fried to a glorious golden brown. If you love your spice, enjoy it with their sambal chilli for that extra kick that will leave you wanting more! ~ @fel_z

caption:
Whip up your very own Canadian dish at home during this #StayHome period with our homemade Canadian Poutine recipe!

Using ingredients we can find in Singapore, this is probably as authentic as it gets. Seeing the end product was absolutely satisfying for me because I loved every aspect of the dish. The way the warm, dark, ambrosial gravy trickled down the fries and chunks of cheese whetted my appetite as soon as I poured the gravy over this delightful meal.

I especially liked how the heat of the gravy melted the cheese, making it look appetising and stringy. The fries were cooked to a crisp golden-brown and I was glad I decided to cook them without peeling the potato skin.

Have you tried Canadian poutine before? ~ @stercei

caption:
There's nothing quite like a hearty brunch plate to kickstart the day. Getting your brunch fix need not always break the bank! @lolascafesg is offering free delivery with minimum spending of S$80.

Staying at home means you can have brunch in your pyjamas! Dig into a plate of flaky croissant sandwiched with fluffy scrambled eggs in the comforts of your home.

No more waiting in line, and their wide variety of food options will make your mornings extra special! ~ @jermtard

caption:
What if I told you that you, too, could cook and bake like famous chefs? We may not be able to match his skill in crafting intricate desserts, but at least we can put together this easy yet scrumptious chocolate cake, as seen from @pierrehermeofficial’s Instagram post.

Pierre Hermé’s 5-Ingredient Chocolate Cake recipe is simple enough, and yields an absolutely heavenly cake. Imagine the soft, crumbly texture of butter cookies, but with the rich, decadent bittersweet notes of dark chocolate.

You might even want to pair your chocolate cake with the most classic of accompaniments: vanilla ice cream. Creamy and cold to the warm and crumbly chocolate cake, this is sure to sate even the direst dessert cravings.

If you leave it in the fridge overnight, it gets a lot denser and more fudgey. Mmm, delicious.

Want to feel like a famous pastry chef for a day? Try this 5-Ingredient Chocolate Cake recipe, and share your experience with us! ~ @colourmeamused
