caption:
Lasagne, Garfield the Cat’s favourite food.

Start by making the pasta sheets. Pour 2 cups of plain flour onto a table and make a well in the center. Crack 3 small eggs into the well and use a fork to whisk the eggs.

Once enough flour and eggs are incorporated, start using your hands to knead the dough for about 6 minutes or so. You will end up with a drier smoother round ball dough after all the flour has been absorbed.

Cover with a cling wrap and let it rest for 20 minutes. After resting, place the dough ball back onto the table and cut into 2 equal halves. With each half, you can make one lasagne.

Use a rolling pin to roll out the pasta and measure with your baking dish to cut out 3 sheets that will cover each layer of lasagne.

You can use our previous Bolognese recipe for the filling, or simply use 2 packets of wagyu Bolognese from @shinsengrocer.

Make a bechamel sauce. Create a simple roux with one tbsp butter and 2 tsp plain flour in a saucepan. Turn on at low flame and slowly wipe the butter around flour filled pan to absorb all the flour.

You will end up with a yellow thick paste. Add fresh milk slowly and let it mix with the roux. The milk will quickly thicken up. Just keep adding until you get a sauce like consistency like what you see in the video. Add grated cheddar and parmesan. Season with black pepper.

Start layering the baking dish with a layer of Bolognese, followed by a pasta sheet. Boil the sheet for 10 seconds prior to placing in the dish. Then add mozzarella cheese and spoon enough bechamel sauce to cover the layer.

Then repeat the same meat, pasta, mozzarella and bechamel layer. For the last layer, add the meat and pasta sheet first. Then add the bechamel layer before adding the mozzarella and some parmesan.

Bake the lasagne in a preheated oven at 180 Celsius no fan for 45 minutes. Once it’s done baking, remove from oven and rest for 20 minutes before eating.

You should get a heavenly golden brown cheesy crust and aroma. And when you cut into it, you should get a multi layered divine lasagne deliciousness :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Oxtail Stew.

You will need oxtails, one celery, one onion and one carrot are the basic ingredients. Red wine, one third can of cherry tomatoes, water and flour round up the rest.

Always brown your meat, in this case, oxtails in a cold pan under low heat. You don’t need oil as the beef has enough fat, and this will render the fat as well.

In a large pot, make a mirepoix, a fancy French word for 爆香, using diced onion, celery and carrot. Keep sautéing until they are soft and aromatic, hence the “Xiang” aspect. Add the seared oxtails into the pot and stir if you want to, though you don’t have to. Just look kinda chefy in case an immediate family is curiously looking on wondering what that gorgeous smell is.

Then add enough red wine. Now never ask a French cook how much, and I will never know, just add until you think it is enough. It is one of those things that it will have that magical wine notes at the end no matter what.

Now add enough water to cover the oxtails. If you have beef stock, better. But where to find beef bones to make stock, but if u do, I will be your best friend now.

Add a third of a can of cherry tomatoes, though plump ones will do as well. Try using Italian ones if possible, cos Italian produce just rocks.

That’s the hard part. Now all u need to do is bring everything to a boil, then lower it to simmering rolling boil. Which means the broth can see only one or two bubbles rolling away, and this is the ideal time to try the Iphone 11 slo mo video shot.

Be sure to check every half hour and top up water, don’t want this delicious dish to burn. I find watching Netflix sitcoms like Big Bang theory or modern family best for the intervals, or if u have an Apple Watch, set that timer which u never thought was useful.

Just an hour or less before that four hours cooking time, add 3 tbsp of plain flour to thicken the sauce and give it a nice glossy look.

Once 4 hours are up, and you have made it thru 8 episodes, plate and serve and enjoy this hearty tasty beef dish :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets

caption:
Decided to take a break from cooking lunch today and have @simonroadhokkienmee118 signature Hokkien Mee instead.

Indeed, the Simon Road uncle has been frying this for decades and it’s one of only 3 hkm which we frequent. His is the dry version which is, we feel, the right way to eat this classic. We hardly touch those super wet and moaty ones.

Fried noodle dishes need to absorb all the stock into the noodles so that the noodles are properly flavoured. That’s why we dislike the soupy ones as they tend to lack that perfect alchemy of flavours, and some can still taste the kee or lye taste of the yellow noodles.

Simon road uncle will always fry and braise the noodles until their tasty broth is fully incorporated, along with the rest of the egg and garlic fragrance, and tinged with a wok hei aroma, it’s quite sensational from first bite till last.

His son, Youri has been learning the ropes and has since picked up most of his dad frying skills, and trust us, it is something that takes time to get this good. Those who have tried our own rendition of hkm will appreciate the efforts just to prepare.

And combined with practice, this is one of our truly iconic Singaporean dishes. And that’s why we wholeheartedly endorse the Simon road stall.

If you live near Kovan, you can visit for tabao now. Else, visit this link for home deliveries ... https://take.sg/s/6582302300 :)))))

caption:
Pulut Inti, Glutinous Coconut Rice Wrapped in Banana Leaf.

A classic dessert this, and oh so good. Start by soaking 1.5 cups of glutinous rice overnight. Next day, transfer to a bowl for steaming. Add 1 packet of coconut milk and half tsp salt. Cut some strips of pandan leaves and spread on top.

Steam for 20 minutes. Open the lid and use a fork to fluff up the rice. Steam for another 5 minutes. Then set aside.

In a pot, add one block of gula melaka or palm sugar, roughly 50g and 60ml water. Add 100g of grated coconut and some more strips of pandan leaves. Stir until the sugar is melted.

Once the sugar is melted and the coconut is coloured an orange, slightly brown colour thoroughly, add a knob of butter and a flour slurry solution. Stir well until you get a coconut paste.

Cut each banana leaf 24cm by 14cm. Then use a ramekin to measure each kueh size, and add glutinous rice in it and flip it onto the leaf. Add some coconut topping on top.

As seen in the video, fold in the longer sides of the lead inward to cover but leave a gap at the center to expose the coconut. Then fold the sides underneath to form a neatly shaped kueh shape, almost like a rice dumpling.

And that’s it, a simple yet tremendously delicious classic dessert that the kids will utterly enjoy :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

Fried Smelt Fish with Baby Spinach Beetroot Salad.

We got these from our favourite fish supplier, @lyhseafood and these beauties are a joy to eat fried.

Simply coat each one with a flour batter seasoned with salt and pepper. And in pan with shallow oil, do a shallow fry each side until they turn golden brown. Roughly a minute plus each side.

We paired them with a simple salad of baby spinach and roasted beetroot. And finish off with a dressing of lemon garlic oil on top. Simple and delicious :)))))

caption:
Pumpkin Rice Cooker, or butternut squash.

For 2 pax, use one cup of rice and wash thoroughly. Add the rice to the rice cooker.

Season roughly 150g chicken breast with one tsp salt, a dash of coriander powder and ginger powder. Mix well and spread them into the rice cooker atop the rice.

Add some chopped pumpkin, about a small bowl with. You can add as much you like as well, and slice 2 button mushrooms and add them into the mix.

Add a cup of water into the rice and let the rice cooker cook it at normal mode until it is done. Once the rice is cooked, open the lid and add a knob of butter and cover for a few minutes.

Once the butter has melted a bit, add chopped scallion and mix everything well. Then, simply spoon into bowls and enjoy. It will have a lovely pumpkin fragrance and sweetness, and a buttery earthiness from the mushrooms. Kids will love this :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Teriyaki Confit Trout from @shinsengrocer.

One of the best ways to cook fish is using the confit method. It is essentially a gentle poach in flavoured oil that results in a very moist and tender flesh, and looks almost uncooked in a way.

Essentially the fish protein is cooked yet retains almost all the moisture and it will have a wondrous texture to the fish. Today we are using a teriyaki marinated trout from @shinsengrocer. As always, pat dry the fish prior to cooking.

Start by pouring enough oil to submerge the entire fish in a saucepan. Add a few sprigs of thyme, a few garlic cloves and some slices of lemon. Then heat it up slowly until it reaches 60 Celsius. You will need a kitchen thermometer to measure this.

Once it reaches 60 Celsius, put the trout inside the pan, and ensure the entire fish is covered in oil. Turn the heat to its lowest flame. The temperature should be maintained between 60 to 65 degrees during the cooking duration. Cook for 10 minutes.

Once the fish is cooked for 10 minutes, remove from the pan. As there is still sufficient teriyaki marinate left to make a sauce, we can use this.

Make a roux by adding one tbsp butter to 2 tsp plain flour in a clean saucepan. Let the butter absorb all the flour before slowly adding the teriyaki sauce and slowly stir until a saucy consistency is reached.

To serve, boil some nai bai as a side. Spoon some sauce at the bottom of the plate. Then add the nai bai, followed by the cooked trout. Quenelle some white truffle paste from @shinsengrocer and add some lemon zest on top to finish.

The joy of eating confit fish is the amazing texture, and you can cook thick red fish like salmon this way too. Enjoy :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Potato Gratin, a simple and delicious French classic.

This is so ridiculously easy to do at home, and will taste so good you wonder why you haven’t tried this earlier.

Start by slicing thinly 4 potatoes and 1 onion. Make a simple roux with one tbsp butter and 2 tsp plain flour in a saucepan. Turn on at low flame and slowly wipe the butter around flour filled pan to absorb all the flour.

You will end up with a yellow thick paste. Add fresh milk slowly and let it mix with the roux. The milk will quickly thicken up. Just keep adding until you get a sauce like consistency like what you see in the video. This is known as a bechamel sauce. Season with a tsp salt and black pepper and set aside.

In a baking dish, layer the onions first on the base of the dish. Then cover the onions fully with a layer of potatoes. Make sure it’s neatly packed.

Spoon the bechamel sauce over the potatoes, and make sure the sauce has fully covered the potatoes also. Then repeat another layer of onions, potatoes and bechamel sauce.

After pouring in the last of the sauce, and ensuring the potatoes are fully submerged in bechamel, sprinkle grated parmesan to fully cover the potato and sauce. We using parmigiana reggiano as it’s just so so good.

Then bake in the oven at 180 Celsius no fan for around 45 minutes. You should get a deliciously tempting golden crust and an accompanying gorgeous aroma to go along with it. If your potatoes are still not soft enough and you are afraid the crust will burn, simply cover the top with an aluminium foil.

Once it’s fully done, take it out and garnish with chopped parsley and fresh pepper. The inside should be creamy once the sauce has been reduced and the combination of potato, onion and meltingly crusty cheese should be undeniably additive :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Red Bean Pancakes, here is the recipe again for those who missed it the first time.

You will need 50g rice flour, 50g plain flour, one egg white and 1 tsp salt. That’s about it, and a good non stick pan.

Mix the two flours, egg white and salt in a mixing bowl and whisk gently until you form a smooth batter.

In a non stick pan, do not oil the pan like most recipes suggest, we find it oil can break the crepe batter easily, but you do need practice in getting this part right. Do not turn on the flame at this point.

Use a ladle and spoon a ladle worth of batter and pour it in the center of the pan and tilt the pan until it fills up every corner, and making sure the batter is still thin enough. Try not to add additional batter in empty spots as this will make the crepe uneven.

Then turn on the flame at its lowest setting and slowly cook the crepe. Will take a few minutes for the batter to dry and the crepe to form. When it’s cooked, it will have a rubbery texture at the edges, use a thin spatula and gently roll and fold the crepe into an empty popiah. Then roll it off onto a plate.

Rinse the pan to cool down and repeat until your batter is finished. Then, with each crepe, add some red bean paste in the centre and fold at each of the 4 sides into a parcel, and flip over.

Now to deep fry. In a wok of boiling hot oil, gently slice each parcel into the oil and deep fry until golden brown, only a few minutes each side.

Remove when done and drain the pancakes of any excess oil and they are done! It should taste crispy and eggy, and delicious for an afternoon snack. Ideal for an afternoon workout for us staying home now :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets

caption: A simple breakfast baking the croissants from @delifrance.sg - using their unbaked ones that you can buy from @redmartcom :)))))

Braised Pork Shoulder with @songfabkt braised pork spice packets.

We tried our their new spice specifically to replicate their signature braised pork trotter dish. And it worked like a charm, we happen to tweaked the recipe as we only have shoulder today.

Sauté some sliced shallots and garlic in a pot of oil until fragrant. Add the pork shoulder, but it’s best with pork belly or pig trotters. Stir well.

Add some light and dark soya to give it colour and seasoning. Put in a few cloves of unpeeled garlic, followed by adding enough water to cover all the meat and ingredients.

Open a packet of the braised spices and you will see 2 sachets that looks like oversized tea bags. Inside it contains a range of herbs and spices, simply put both inside the broth. Simmer for at least 3 hours.

Occasionally top up the water every half hour or so, then after 2 hours, add some flour slurry to thicken the broth and make it glossy.

After 3 hours, the pork should be tender and falling apart upon any human contact. Simply serve in a bowl or claypot and enjoy. And what we did tonight is to have it with rice porridge with that tasty sauce and some greens. Yummy :)))))
comments: ['You inspire me so much on video taking on my food recipes!!! And everything you cook looks so perfect!']

caption:
Puttanesca Linguine, an Italian classic pasta recalling the Mediterranean.

Today, we visit the south of Italy for one of the lesser known classics found here. Dispensing with cheese and pancetta, the main ingredients are olives, capers, anchovies and tomatoes, sun dried ones even better.

Start by boiling the linguine for about 6.5 minutes of the total 9 minutes cooking time. The remaining time will be finished in the sauce. We using our favourite @barilla brand as they consistently provide the best texture.

Strain the pasta and keep the pasta water. In a pan with a generous amount of extra virgin olive oil, sauté some anchovy fillets. These are not ikan bilis, but cured ones that are usually sold in bottles soaked in oil.

Add in thinly slice garlic, and thinly sliced as it will prevent it from burning too fast and allow the garlic oil to be nicely formed. Add in about 8 olives and a handful of capers. Stir and mix well.

Next, add one or 2 canned tomatoes and let the tomatoes soften. Add in a ladle of pasta water and stir. Throw in the linguine and quickly mix and toss if possible.

After a minute or so, the sauce will be absorbed into the pasta. Keep tossing until the water is almost gone. Then turn off the flame, and add in chopped parsley, black pepper and more extra virgin olive oil.

Give it one last good toss as this will allow the olive oil to emulsify with the liquid to give each strand of linguine a luscious and almost creamy feel.

Serve in a plate and enjoy this refreshing and healthier pasta :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Shakshuka, a Middle Eastern breakfast favourite.

Shakshuka in Arabic means a haphazard mixture, or in other words, a rojak to us. So feel free to replace the ingredients with whatever you have.

Ours begin with sauté sliced onions and carrots in a cast iron pan with oil until they are soft. We use cast iron as we can just bake the whole pan in the oven later.

Add broccoli, some sliced sausages and a couple of canned tomatoes and fry some more. Then season with half tsp salt, a dash of cumin, cayenne pepper and smoked paprika. Stir well.

Break 2 eggs into the pan or more if you like. Then simply bake in the oven at 180 Celsius for about 5 minutes. You just want to get the egg whites set but let the yolks remain creamy.

Once it’s done with the baking part, remove from oven. Break the yolks when you eat and mix it all around. It’s so good and hearty to start the day with :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.
comments: ['Wow looks easy. Ok this weekend 🙌']

caption:
Classic Jack Place Steak using Montreal Australia Marbled Steak from @shinsengrocer.

You will need a grill pan like the one in the video, though using a regular will do. You won’t get the lovely grill marks without the grill pan do.

The steak from @shinsengrocer comes pre seasoned so you just need to heat up the pan until it’s very hot before you add it in. As there is some fat on the beef, no oil is needed.

Steaks with this thickness usually take about 3 minutes to cook fully, so you should flip around the 1.5 minutes mark. As you need around that much time to get a nice crust and grill marks too, so the best doneness is medium pink.

Naturally we always hear from TV cooking shows that medium rare is the best doneness, but that’s for thicker cuts like thick striploin and tenderloin. Thinner cuts, we need to weigh getting better crusts for flavour against getting that medium rare texture.

We also didn’t baste the steak today as this is old school western Hainanese style we shooting for, so we added the slab of butter after we placed the cooked steak on a plate. Simply add the slab of butter on top of the steak.

As an added touch, we spooned some white truffle pate from @shinsengrocer as well, for that extra oomph. Garnish with some vegetables of your selection on the side.

When you eat, simply wipe that butter all over the steak before cutting into it. Yums :)))))
comments: ['😘😋😘😋', 'This looks perfect 😍', 'Looks great!']

caption:
Banana Leaf Baked Spicy Seabass.

Here’s a great way to cook fresh fish, especially when we still have this 2 week old seabass from @lyhseafood. And amazingly it still tastes fresher than most fish from supermarkets.

Blitz 4 garlic, 1 shallot, handful of dried shrimp, 1 lemongrass stalk, juice from half a big lime and 2 chillies until you form a paste.

Sauté one sliced onion in a pan of oil until soft and fragrant, and when they are, add in the spicy paste and mix well. Season with 1 tsp salt and add some water if it gets too dry.

On a baking tray lined with aluminium foil, place one complete banana leave on top as the base for this fish. You can get the leaves from @redmartcom.

Place your seabass or any white fish on top. You can use a fillet or if it’s big enough to fit on the leaf, an entire fish. Spread the cooked spicy paste on top of the fish.

Cover with another banana leaf and secure the sides and edges with toothpicks. Refer to the video for this. Then bake in an oven at 180 Celsius for about 15 minutes or so until the fish is fully cooked.

When it’s done, simply transfer to a serving plate and remove the toothpicks and top leaf. It should smell amazing and when you use a fork to pry open the fish, it should be tender, flaky and moist. And incredibly flavorful :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Here’s a recap of Doraemon favourite dessert, Doriyaki bean paste pancake sandwich.

You need 80g plain flour, 40g sugar, honey, baking powder, 2 eggs, oil and water.

Make the batter first by adding the sugar into a bowl and add one tbsp honey. Break two eggs and whisk like there’s no tomorrow hehe. This is to introduce air into the mixture and after a few minutes, the mixture will start to foam and turn paler, and will have more liquid. This is a much better way to use your whisking muscles than to make some diabetic Korean kopi C which we will also never make here hehe.

Once the egg mixture is foamy and has a nice viscosity, add the 80g flour and half tsp baking powder and stir subtly until it foams into a nice yellow and eggy batter. Refrigerate for 15 minutes and after taking it out, add one tbsp plain water just to loosen the batter.

We used our homemade red bean paste from a few days ago, but you can use pre-made ones as well. Add a little oil and stir well to smooth out the filling.

In a non stick pan, pour a ladle of egg batter into the centre and let it naturally spread out to form a round pancake shape. It will cook very quickly in a minute or two, so use a spatula to loosen the edges and get ready to flip.

Once it’s dry on the bottom side, quickly flip and cook the other side, which will tend to cook faster as the pan gets hotter. Make two pieces for each dorayaki sandwich. 
Once done, spoon some red bean filling on one piece and cover with another piece to form a sandwich. Use a cling wrap to tightly wrap around the dorayaki to get the chubby UFO shape. Leave for 10 minutes before unwrapping.

And there you have it, an aromatic eggy red bean or azuki Japanese pancake sandwich! A great way to start the day during stay home :))))) Check my profile highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
A nourishing slow cooked soup tonight of pork ribs, snow pear, sweet dates, kernel almonds and white fungus, brewed for the better part of a day in our trusty slow cooker.

So much natural sweetness that even the little ones will take to this easily we think :)))))

Rice Cooker Dumplings, a ba zhang shortcut hack.

We have some balance of the rice dumpling filling from last week so decided to do a shortcut version for those who find it challenging to tie the actual ones.

Just a quick recap of the meat fillings - In a fresh wok of oil, fry another 3 minced garlic, a handful of dried shrimp and 1 chopped shallot until fragrant. Add the marinated pork, peanuts, dried mushrooms and chestnuts. Fry and stir until everything is properly mixed. After about 5 minutes, set aside and let it cool down. Soak one cup of glutinous rice overnight.

To a cup of water, add 1 tsp light soya, 1 tsp dark soya, 1 tsp oyster sauce, 1 tsp sesame oil and a dash of five spice powder. Stir well.

Add the soaked rice to a rice cooker and pour in the soya mixture and stir a bit. Let it cook in rice cooker until it’s fully cooked.

Put a cling wrap into a bowl to prevent sticking as glutinous rice is rather sticky. Spoon enough rice to cover one third of the bowl. Then add in the meat filling and fill the rest of the bowl with rice to cover.

On a plate, it’s optional to put a few bamboo leaves as this will rather give a more zhang vibe. Flip the bowl over onto the plate and gently lift at the sides and you should see a cutesy round shaped rice dumpling.

It should taste similar sans the boiled bamboo fragrance, though you can always boil the leaves too to get that aroma. :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Almond Butter Notella Braided Swirl Bread.

In a bread maker, add 280g bread flour, 50g butter, 3 tbsp sugar, 1 tsp salt, 1/2 egg and 160ml milk. Add in 1 tsp instant yeast and set it to bread mode and let the bread maker work it’s magic

Once it’s finished, pour the dough onto a flour dusted table and roll it out with a rolling pin into a flat squarish shape. Apply half of it with almond butter and another half with notella. You can use normal Nutella for an unhealthy rendition.

Then slowly roll up the dough from the bottom to eventually form a cylindrical shape. See the video to see how to use a dough cutter to make an incision right down the center to expose the nut butter cross section and into two ends. Leave the top section uncut.

Take each side of each end and cross over the other like tying a shoe lace. Again refer to the video. You will end up with a braided looking bread shape like what you see in the video.

Rest for 45 minutes in a warm enough environment. Then bake at 180 Celsius no fan for 20 minutes. At the end, healthy almond butter notella braided swirl bread that will look visually arresting also :)))))

caption:
A simple and refreshing dinner of herbal chicken mee sua.

Just a simple steamed boneless chicken leg with Angelica root, goji berries, dried scallops and red dates. Season with salt, pepper, Chinese wine and sesame oil. Let it steam in a wok for about 25 minutes.

After steaming, simply slice the chicken into slices, and seen here served with mee sua and a side of dried shrimp cabbage. We finished it in minutes :)))))

Kimchi Fried Rice, easy and delicious.

Here’s how to do this at home, you need to have kimchi of course, which you can easily procure at the local supermarkets. And as an optional extra, we are using smoked bratwurst though bacon or luncheon meat will do just as well.

Have some cooked rice ready, and contrary to popular belief, you don’t need to use overnight rice. What you can do is to cook the rice a few hours in advance, and once it’s cook, open the lid and let it dry out for an hour to 2. The key is to remove any excess moisture so that the rice won’t be clumpy when fried.

Start in a wok with some oil and fry the meat chopped in small dices. Fry a few minutes until it’s lightly browned. If your kimchi is still in large pieces, make sure to cut them into smaller and thinner slices beforehand.

Add the kimchi, as to how much it’s up to you. We would suggest about 2 handfuls should be sufficient but go crazy with more if you adore the Korean pickled cabbage.

Stir and mix well with the meat. We add a canned tomato and some of the juices to give it some hearty acidity, but you can substitute with Korean gochujang sauce for an extra spicy kick.

Next add the rice and stir well. Use a spatula to break up any clumpy rice and get every grain properly coated with the kimchi sauce. It should look bright red when it’s done. 
Add a dash of sesame oil and chopped scallion. Turn off the flame and serve. We are using a shallow cast iron pan as it resembles those metal pans that Korean places usually use.

For garnishing, cut a dried seaweed sheet into very thin strips and place in the center of the rice. Then sprinkle some white sesame seeds and you are done! And just to make it more Korean, stick 2 long spoons at opposite sides of the pan.

Add a sunny side egg as an extra and enjoy the simple but highly tasty fried rice :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

Doesn’t this make you want to watch Kdramas now? We highly recommend shows like Healer, Pinocchio and Coffee Prince. And DOTS of course where we first saw this dish hehe.

caption:
Homemade Ondeh Ondeh, also known as Klepon in Indonesia.

Start by opening a packet of grated coconut, which you can get from @redmartcom. Break it into pieces as it’s probably quite hardened when you open. Add half tsp salt. Steam the coconut on a plate in a wok for about 15 minutes. Set aside for later.

Cut about 12 pandan leaves into shorter lengths and add them to a blender with about 100ml water. Blitz until you get pandan juice. Strain the juice. Chop palm sugar or gula melaka into small chunks. You can buy this from @redmartcom also.

In a whisking bowl, add 100g glutinous rice flour, 40g tapioca flour, 2 tbsp sugar and the strained pandan juice. Use a spatula to mix until you get an Incredible Hulk green dough. Knead until it’s smooth all around.

Then tear the dough into roughly 20g sized pieces, each making one Ondeh ball. Flatten it and add a piece of palm sugar and fold until you cover the sugar. Roll into a round ball. You should be able to make a dozen balls.

Boil a pot of water and add the balls into the bubbling water. It will initially sink to the bottom of the pot. It will need between 10 to 15 minutes to fully cook the Ondeh balls.

Around 10 mins or so, the balls will start to float up. Let it cook another 2 to 5 minutes to allow the gula melaka to fully melt inside. Once it’s cooked, strain the balls of excess water.

Put the balls in a plate with the grated coconut and roll them until they are fully coated. After which, simply serve in a plate.

It should be pandan chewy bouncy on the outside. Inside, it should also be palm sugary lava gooey inside, and that combination of flavours and texture is what fans of this will swoon over :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Japanese Kare Udon, Curry Noodles.

Here’s a quick and tasty meal to whip up in minutes during this circuit breaker light period. Just get these items from @shinsengrocer - ready to eat Japanese curry, or Kare as they call it, their tasty gyo or fish udon and a chicken fillet. We always like the superb ones from @benjachickensingapore.

Lightly blanche the udon for a minute and set aside. Then chop the chicken into chunks and fry them in a pan of oil until they brown and is fully cooked. Takes about 5 minutes or more at medium heat.

Then add the Japanese curry. Normally you need to cook the vegetables separately and add a Japanese curry cube to make the curry, but @shinsengrocer has done all that. 
Usually you will eat this with rice, but trust us, it’s even better with noodles. So simply add the readymade curry into the pan with the chicken and mix them up well.

Next, just the udon and toss until they are evenly coated and you are done! Simply serve into bowls and garnish with a little scallion for colour. And enjoy :)))))

Quattro Formaggi Pizza with Porcini and Truffle Paste, four cheese goodness,

Using the same pizza recipe from the original margherita pizza from a few days back, we replaced the tomato filling with a gorgeous four cheese and porcini one. Here’s a recap of the dough recipe.

Dissolve 1 tsp instant yeast to 160ml warm water. In a mixing bowl, add 250g plain flour and 1/2 tsp salt. Stir to mix well. Then slowly add the yeast mixture into the flour until they are fully integrated. Stir to form a shaggy dough.

Once you get that wet dough, pour it out onto a flour dusted table. Then knead until you form a smooth dough ball. Cover with a damp cloth and let it rest in a warm place for about 2 hours.

After resting, cut the dough into halves. Each half will make one pizza base. Shape each dough into another dough ball and then rest for another 2 hours.

After the dough ball has rested enough, place it on a flour dusted table again. Punch it down with your fist to flatten it. Then spread it out as much as you can. You can hold it in the air with both hands and just roll it like you see in the video.

Once it’s thin enough and it’s the size of a regular pizza shape, place the dough on a round baking pan. Add four different cheeses, we chose parmigiana reggiano, cheddar, mozzarella and gruyere cheese.

In addition, we soaked some dry porcini for half an hour and placed the soak porcini around the pizza, and drizzled some of the porcini water around too. To make it even more luxurious, we added some truffle paste from @shinsengrocer.

Bake it in a preheated oven at 250 Celsius or at your highest available temperature for 8 to 10 minutes. When the cheese has completely melted and has a light golden crust, remove from oven.

It should look like golden brown cheese nirvana and the lovely aroma of melted cheese and porcini, and should be delicious to cheese lovers everywhere :)))))
comments: ['😋😋', 'My favourite 🤩']

caption:
Saturday Waffles with Candied Bacon and Scrambled Eggs.

Make your candied bacon by spreading sugar over strips of bacon and baking them in the oven at 190 Celsius for 12 minutes.

To make the batter for waffles, which 1 cup plain flour, 2 tsp baking powder, 1 tsp sugar, 3 tbsp coconut oil, 1 cup milk and 1 tbsp water until you form a smooth batter.

Simply pour the batter into your waffle maker and let it cook until it’s done. Yums, the smell of fresh waffles on a weekend morning is just so good.

Cook some scrambled eggs which you can find in another post here, just have to scroll back to find it hehe. Then just add the eggs and bacon to your freshly made waffles.

It’s a simple and easy to do waffle breakfast that will surely please the family :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Seafood Claypot Noodles using leftover bkt broth from @songfabkt.

Don’t throw away excess bkt broth next time you order this at home, as the tasty soup can make for an even tastier dish the next day. We had some leftover from yesterday to make this claypot noodles even better.

Cook some claypot noodles by blanching in water for a few minutes until they turn soft. Then fry half a sliced onion in oil until fragrant. Again, we had some leftover onion from lunch.

Add about 4 scallops that have been cut into halves. Stir and toss for awhile. Then add some fish chunks. We still had some batang leftover from last week’s army stew, and they still taste fresh. Again, kudos to @lyhseafood for giving us such good produce.

Stir and toss again, then add the blanched noodles and stir/toss again. Next, season with a tbsp light soya and some white pepper. Add some broth, and we using the delicious peppery bkt broth from @songfabkt from yesterday’s lunch.

Let the noodles braise for a short while. Transfer to a claypot on a stove and cover for a minute or so until it boils. When it reaches an enticing claypot bubbling boil, remove and serve.

As you can tell, we are using a lot of leftovers tonight, which is a great way to save costs and avoid food wastage. At the same time, the dinner still tastes fresh and delicious :)))))

caption:
Mount Karubi Don - Homemade Wagyu Beef Rice Bowl.

Here’s how you can assemble your own wagyu don at home without breaking the bank. We happen to have some excellent beef short ribs from @yakiniku_plaza.

Cook some white rice. In a pan of oil, fry half an onion that has been sliced. Fry until they are soft and translucent. Once they are caramelised, they will be gorgeously sweet. Season with a tbsp light soya and one tbsp mirin. Set aside.

You can use any beef shabu for this also, but it’s better to get a thicker cut ones. The better the quality the beef, the better this rice bowl will turn out.

Season with just some sea salt and black pepper. At home, it’s hard to replicate a proper charcoal fire yakiniku experience, so we settled for a grill pan. Though any pan will do, just that you can get nice grill marks from a grill pan.

Get the pan nice and hot, and simply cook it for a minute or less each side. Don’t add  oil especially for wagyu cuts as they have enough fat on it’s own, and don’t overcook. Beef this thin and good, you want to preserve the tender moist texture and flavours.

Once the beef is cooked, time to plate up. In a bowl of rice, layer the caramelised onions first, followed by placing the beef slices around the onions to form a mountain shape. See the video for this.

Then just add some more onions and garnish with either scallions or leeks. Sprinkle some furikake for that complete Japanese feel and voila, Mount Karubi Don is born :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Eating healthy is something we always advocate, and cooking at home is one way to ensure healthier standards around the household.

We also like to start our day with an energy boosting one with lots of vitamins and nutrients, and a good dose of probiotics.

Hence, today is Chobani Greek yogurt parfait, homemade matcha granola and a variety of citrus fruits :)))))

Taking it easy tonight with a simple 8 hour slow cooker soup.

Just put pork ribs, longan, couple of corn 🌽 and carrots into a slow cooker for 8 hours. A nourishing and naturally sweet broth for the day :)))))
comments: ['the color of that soup is amazing!!! cant imagine how good this tastes😍', 'Oh that soup looks like pure gold!', '👍', 'Must be super sweet 😋 I love corn in my slow cooked soups']

caption:
Simple Nonya Curry Chicken using the curry powder from @shermayssingaporefinefood.

Start by blitzing one garlic, one shallot and a few slices of ginger into a paste. Use half of a packet of @shermayssingaporefinefood Nonya Curry Chicken powder which is enough for 2 persons. Pour half the packet into 150ml water and stir well to dissolve the powder.

Add the minced garlic, shallot and ginger into the curry mixture. Then pour this mixture into a bowl of 250g chicken. We using chicken wings today. Use your hands to marinate the chicken evenly and thoroughly. Rest for 20 minutes.

Fry one chopped onion in a wok of oil until fragrant. Once the onions are soft, add in the chicken and 2 chopped potatoes. Mix well before pouring in the rest of the chicken marinate and add enough water to cover the chicken.

Season with about a tsp of salt for taste. Then leave it to gently simmer for at least half an hour to cook the chicken and for the potatoes to get soft.

After half an hour, add in either coconut cream or milk to thicken the curry and make it creamy or lemak. Turn off the flame and serve. Easy and tasty :)))))

caption:
When you can’t get enough of HK French Toasts especially during this stay home time, you make your own.

Get thick toasts for this though any normal white bread can still work. We using our homemade Hokkaido milk bread which is even more delicious.

First, trim off the crust edges. Use 2 slices for each hk toast. Spread smooth peanut butter on both slices, we using the healthy almond one from @scoopwholefoods_sg. Cover and make the egg coating.

Add 3 tbsp of fresh milk to 3 eggs and beat them well. Use a wide enough plate or pan that can hold the width of your toast. Get your oil hot and ready first before you coat as this is crucial.

Use a pot wide enough to hold the toast and allow it to turn on its sides. Heat up the oil to 150 Celsius. To test, drop a few drops of the egg coat and it should sizzle and fry into a batter almost instantly.

Set the stove to medium heat. Coat the toast with the egg solution on every side evenly. Each side only a few seconds as the idea is not to let it soak too much for too long. Once it’s all coated, immediately drop it into the pot of bubbling oil.

Each side should only take 30 seconds to get brown. You should get crusty fried egg shards on the sides, this will be so delicious! Use tongs to flip to the edges to get all 6 sides fully fried. On the last side, which should be the other flat side, set heat to maximum to get full deep fry mode. This will allow the toast not to get too much excess oil.

Drain the toast on paper towels to remove any last bit of oil. To finish, add a thick slice of cold butter and drizzle cold maple syrup on top and you are down! It may be called French toast, and as much as I regard French cooking, this is one thing that Asians are much better at pulling off :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Bak Zhang Rice Dumplings.

Dragon Boat Festival is just around the corner and with saving costs foremost on our minds, we decided to make our own instead of buying from outside.

Start by soaking 500g glutinous rice, 12 chestnuts and bamboo leaves overnight. Also, soak about 6 dried mushrooms for 2 hours.

Marinate 250g pork shoulder or belly with 1 tbsp light soya, 1 tbsp dark soya, 1 tbsp sesame oil, 1 tbsp oyster sauce, 3 minced garlic, 1 chopped shallot and some 5 spice powder. Add a dash of white pepper also.

In a wok of oil, fry 3 minced garlic and 1 chopped shallot until fragrant. Add the glutinous rice and mix well. Season with 1 tbsp light soya, 1 tbsp dark soya, 1 tbsp sesame oil, 1 tbsp oyster sauce and some 5 spice powder. Stir until the rice is evenly coated, then set aside and let it cool down.

In a fresh wok of oil, fry another 3 minced garlic, a handful of dried shrimp and 1 chopped shallot until fragrant. Add the marinated pork, dried mushrooms and chestnuts. Fry and stir until everything is properly mixed. After about 5 minutes, set aside and let it cool down.

For each dumping take 2 bamboo leaves and fold at the center to form a triangle cup as seen in the video. Spoon some rice to fill one third of the capacity. Add a chestnut and a piece of pork.

Then add a chestnut, half a mushroom, some braised peanuts (from can) and half a salted egg yolk. You can also add an abalone as an option.

Fold the the flap of the lead to cover the base of the dumpling and fold in any other flap. Ensure it is tight and there are no gaps to form a taut pyramid shape.

We tie the dumpling strings to a hangar, but you can improvise with whatever is convenient. Use the string to tie around the dumpling and ensure it is tight. Make 12 dumplings with this recipe.

Then boil the dumplings in a wok of water for 45 minutes and it should be done. If you didn’t leave any gaps, the dumpling should look firm and neat.

We still need more practice with our dumpling tying skills, but this way is certainly more affordable than buying commercial ones outside. And equally as tasty :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets

caption:
After cooking exclusively at home and making all our meals for 2 months, we decided to mark the end of cb with a meal from outside.

And thanks to our friends from @songfabkt, we had a marvelous Bak Kut Teh lunch with braised pig triggers and fried you tiao. When it comes to bkt, we still defer to them as they still have a fine balance of savoury, meaty, garlicky and peppery notes without being over-sweet.

And also, we are busy with making something today that we thought to take it easy for lunch :)))))

caption:
Cone Bread Rolls.

Freshly baked bread is the best thing to wake up to! And this is one simple and easy bread recipe to do at home.

In a bread maker, add 280g bread flour, 50g butter, 3 tbsp sugar, 2 tbsp milk powder, 1 tsp salt, 1/2 egg, 160ml water and 1 tsp instant yeast. Set to bread dough mode and let it start and work it’s way till it is done. If you don’t have a bread machine, you can knead mix and knead by hand or mixed too.

Once the dough is finished in the bread maker, pour it out onto a flour dusted table. Use a dough cutter to cut into 12 equal portions. Each portion will make one bread roll. 
Roll each portion into a dough ball. Cover with a cloth and rest for 15 minutes. After resting, roll out each ball into thin long shape as seen in the video.

Use a cone mold like seen in the video and twirl the cylinder like dough around the cone to form a bread roll cone. Then cover with cloth and rest for an hour.

After the second resting, bake in a preheated oven at 180 Celsius fan mode for 15 minutes or until it’s perfectly golden brown.

Remove and enjoy! It is good on it’s own and nothing smells like a perfect morning then the aroma of freshly baked bread. And ideal with a dollop of cold butter :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Pad Gaprao, or simply known as Thai Basil Minced Pork.

We often find this dish in Thai eateries, here’s how to make this simple dish at home. Gaprao is Thai for holy basil, which is different from the Italian basil we see in pasta. It has a more minty herbaceous aroma.

Start by making the sauce by adding together, 1 tbsp fish sauce, 1 tbsp light soya, 1 tbsp dark soya, 1 tbsp oyster sauce and 2 tbsp water. Optional add tbsp sugar. Mix well and set aside.

In a wok of hot oil, fry 2 minced garlic and 1 finely chopped chilli until they are fragrant. Add 200g to 250g minced pork and stir. Make sure to use a spatula to break out the meat to avoid clumps.

Once the meat has sufficiently browned, add the sauce and mix well until the meat is fully coated. Then add half a chopped onion and a handful of chopped long beans. Mix well again.

When the onions and long beans are soft, turn off the flame and add in a handful of Thai basil leaves. Toss quickly in the residual heat to somewhat blanche the basil. And that’s it, easy.

This is best eaten with white rice, so simply pour the Pad Gaprao over the rice and enjoy. It’s also nice to have a sunny side up egg with this too :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Crispy Salmon, how to get it right.

Always pat dry your salmon before cooking it, and make sure it’s at room temperature. So, don’t take it out from the refrigerator too late.

Season with sea salt is best, as the courser particles will not dissolve that fast and make it overly salty. Season liberally also with both salt and black pepper on both sides. Salt will also help to extract any additional moisture, and that will help in making the skin crispy.

In a pan with a generous amount of oil at medium heat, always make sure the pan is well heated up before putting the fish in. And always start with skin side down, and a good non stick pan is best.

Slide the pan a bit to maw sure the skin is not sticking to the pan, and also only to turn the fish once. Fish like salmon only takes 4 to 5 minutes at most. Which means it should take not more than 2.5 minutes for each side, which is sufficient to crisp up the skin.

Once the skin side is crispy, flip the fish over and drop a spoon of butter which will melt very quickly. Use a spoon to baste the fish like what you see in the video.

Use a pair of tongs to feel the sides of the fish. It should feel firmer than when it was raw, but not too tough until it’s hard. Once you get that nice firm and toi toi texture, remove the fish from the heat and let it rest for a few minutes.

Your salmon skin will also dry off and you will end up with a perfectly seared and crispy skin, and a flaky and slightly pink and moist, tender flesh inside :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Dutch Baby Pancake.

Not your regular pancakes, this is really delicious and looks so good. You will need a cast iron pan or a pan that can be baked in an oven as most standard pans have materials that are not conducive in an oven.

Warm up half a cup of milk. In a whisking bowl, add 1/2 cup plain flour, 1/2 cup warmed milk, 2 large eggs, 1/2 tsp salt and 2 tbsp sugar. Whisk until you get a smooth batter.

Heat up your 9 inch cast iron skillet in an oven until it’s piping hot. Drop 2 tbsp butter into it and it will immediately fizzle. Use a spoon to wipe the butter all around the pan. Immediately pour in the batter and spread it evenly around the skillet.

Bake the pancake in the pan in a preheated oven at 220 Celsius no fan for around 15 minutes. After 10 minutes, it should puff up considerably. Ensure the center is properly cooked and set before removing it from the oven.

Once you take the pancake out, dust some icing sugar on the base before adding fruits of your choice. Then dust some more icing sugar and add some maple syrup and it’s done! Delicious and full of fruit vitamins :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Homemade Margherita Italian Pizza.

This is easy and cheap to do at home. Now, we won’t be able to achieve charred crusts like those found in Italian woodfire pizza joints, but this is a home oven version using fresh ingredients and making pizza dough from scratch.

Dissolve 1 tsp instant yeast to 160ml warm water. In a mixing bowl, add 250g plain flour and 1/2 tsp salt. Stir to mix well. Then slowly add the yeast mixture into the flour until they are fully integrated. Stir to form a shaggy dough.

Once you get that wet dough, pour it out onto a flour dusted table. Then knead until you form a smooth dough ball. Cover with a damp cloth and let it rest in a warm place for about 2 hours.

After resting, cut the dough into halves. Each half will make one pizza base. Shape each dough into another dough ball and then rest for another 2 hours. In the meantime, make the tomato sauce.

The best tomatoes are the ones from San Marzano, but it’s hard to get those. Either get a good Italian canned tomatoes, but if not, just get any canned ones will do. Blitz 3 or 4 canned tomatoes until it turns into a paste. Season with 1/2 tsp salt, some oregano and a dash of extra virgin olive oil.

After the dough ball has rested enough, place it on a flour dusted table again. Punch it down with your fist to flatten it. Then spread it out as much as you can. You can hold it in the air with both hands and just roll it like you see in the video.

Once it’s thin enough and it’s the size of a regular pizza shape, place the dough on a round baking pan. Spoon the tomato sauce onto the pizza base and spread it with the base of a ladle evenly.

Next, add balls of mozzarella cheese all around the pizza and some basil leaves. Bake it in a preheated oven at 250 Celsius or at your highest available temperature for 8 to 10 minutes. When the cheese has completely melted and has a light golden crust, remove from oven.

Serve it on a board or plate and cut it with a pizza cutter and enjoy! Pizzas are best eaten when it’s piping hot, and that’s why having this, you are unlikely to go back to fast food ones :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Tom Yum Rice Cooker, a taste of Siam.

To make this, there’s 2 ways. One is to use our previous Tom Yum broth, which you can find by scrolling through our feed. The other much easier way is to use this organic Tom Yum paste which you find via @shermayssingaporefinefood and the associated online grocer.

Dissolve 2 tsp of the Tom Yum into a cup of warm water. Then pour the mixture into a rice cooker filled with a cup of rice. Good enough for 2 persons.

You can also to add some optional ingredients to make it even more fragrant. Crush some lemongrass with the back of a knife and chop them. Add to the rice cooker. Cut some slices of galangal and add them too.

Simply set to rice cooker mode and let it cook till it is done. In the meantime, you can marinate about 6 deshelled and deveined tiger prawns with 1 tsp fish sauce and some white pepper. Prepare some broccoli and cherry tomatoes as accompaniments.

When the rice is cooked, open the rice cooker and add the broccoli and tomatoes and cook for 5 minutes. Then open again and add the prawns and cook for 3 to 5 minutes until they are pinkly cooked. Add a tsp of fish sauce around the rice also when you add the prawns.

When the prawns are done, you can simply spoon everything into a bowl and garnish with some sliced green chilies and enjoy :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Cheaper to make our own açai at home.

Simply put two açai bars (can buy from redmart) for 2 portions and add one banana if you have. Remember that the açai is unsweetened so add as much sugar as you desire, but the banana is more than sweet enough for us.

We added some frozen raspberries into the blender and blitz. Once it’s fully blended, you should get açai the same as you would outside.

We had it with some konnyaku jelly and fruits this morning :)))))
comments: ['Hi, can you please post the video recipe for konnyaku jelly again?  Thank you.']

caption:
Simplest Chicken Stew Ever.

Using the leftover veggies from @greenies.sg, we dumped one big chicken leg, chopped potatoes, chopped celery, chopped carrots, sliced onions, canned tomatoes into our trusty little slow cooker.

Add enough water to cover the ingredients and let it slow cook for at least 8 hours. When you are ready to eat, just add enough salt to taste and break some basil leaves into the broth for a lovely herbaceous fragrance.

It will be just perfect for a hearty meal, and you can have it with baguette or rice. So refreshing after a day of wfh :)))))

caption:
Butadon with Egg.

When you see shabu shabu pork in supermarkets, don’t just think of using them for hotpot, as you will need to buy a bunch of other stuff just to do a hotpot. Instead here’s a simple rice bowl that’s fast and easy to whip up.

We are using the pork tricol roll from @yakiniku_plaza which you can go to for online home deliveries. They have a range of premium Japanese beef and pork items suited for simple yet tasty meals.

In a pan of oil at medium heat, sweat half a sliced onions until they are slightly charred, soft and translucent. Once they are soft, add your pork shabu into the mix. Use a pair of tongs to separate the pieces as they tend to stick together.

Once the meat is seared for about a minute or less, add 1 tbsp light soya (or 2 tbsp udon/soba sauce), 1 tbsp mirin, half tsp sugar and 2 tbsp water. Simmer for about a minute.

Turn the heat to low and add in one beaten egg and cover with lid for about 10 seconds. Open the lid and wait for the base of the egg to set and see that the egg is not watery. If it’s just moist, it will be fine as the egg will continue to cook on its own residual heat.

Pour the pork and egg mixture onto a bowl of white rice, preferably Japanese rice. Then garnish it with scallion and furikake and it’s done! Easy and delicious, and much more convenient than doing a steamboat :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Here’s a recap of that famous grilled cheese sandwich as seen in the movie, Chef. And boy, is this so stretchy good.

Butter both slices of a bread, we doing this with our own Hokkaido milk bread yields the best result. We use ghee here cos it’s clarified and mighty delicious, especially with our local QBB green tin brand.

In a pan of oil at low to medium heat, put both slices in simultaneously, buttered side faced down. Rub a little of the oil to prevent sticking. Immediately add the cheeses. We chose gouda, emental, cheddar and mozzarella, but you can go crazy with your own combinations.

After about a minute, cover your cheeses with the other slice and butter the top of it again with more butter. Yes, butter is marvelous here as it gives tremendous flavor. Then after another minute, flip over and toast the other side good.

Then after another minute, your cheeses should melt nicely. Now, if your bread is a bit thick like ours, do not fret if the cheese takes longer to melt. Simply send to the oven at 220 Celsius and toast for another 5 minutes with a foil wrap to get that final melting done.

Once the cheese has melted, then comes the really fun part. Cut into half and hear that symphony of crust crackling. Then, pull them apart for that cheesy stretch effect, fantastic for that instagram video.

But the true test is that first bite, crispy crackling of bread in your mouth up to your eardrums. And that combination of umami cheese goodness, and that buttery toast sensation. The kind of breakfast to salivate over, so go make some now yourself :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
A healthy Sunday start with Chobani Greek yoghurt, fruits and homemade matcha granola. Here’s how to make fresh and healthy matcha infused granola at home.

All you need is to mix 1 cup rolled oats, 1/2 cup unsalted and unsweetened almond + cashew + hazelnuts, 1/2 cup pine + chia seeds, 1/2 tsp salt, 2 tsp matcha power, 2 tbsp coconut oil and 2 tbsp honey in a mixing bowl.

After a good mix, roll out the mixed granola onto a baking tray lined with baking paper. Spread it out evenly to cover every corner. Then send it to the oven for 15 minutes at 180 Celsius at no fan mode. Every five minutes, just stir it around to prevent any burning.

Once it’s nicely toasted, take it out of the oven and add some dried sultana, freeze dried strawberries and cacao nibs to complete this crunchy and nutritious granola. Pour it all into a glass jar and you can use it for many days of breakfast :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the granola video snippets.

Crispy Salmon in Vegetable Broth.

Thanks to our friends at @greenies.sg, we had a bounty of vegetables and fruits today, and what’s fun about them is they also cut some of these veggies for you, making it easier to work with.

And the first thing we thought of to maximize such nice vegetables was to make a delicious vegetable broth to go with a crispy pan seared salmon. We will show the salmon searing technique separately so watch for this in a later post.

To make the stock, simply put in a slow cooker, a chopped onion, a few stalks of chopped celery, one chopped carrot and some white cabbage. Add water to fill up the pot and set to slow cook for at least 8 hours. You can do this in pot over a stove also, just be mindful to top up water every once in a while.

We will not eat or use the vegetables in the slow cooker. The veggies we use in the actual dish will be roasted instead, as they taste amazingly tasty sweet when you cook them this way.

Slice the vegetables very thinly so you can roast them quickly without burning them. Lay these potatoes neatly on a baking tray lined with aluminum foil. Potatoes, carrots, celery, broccoli and beetroot.

Season them with sea salt and drizzle with olive oil. Roast in the oven at 200 Celsius for between 10 to 12 minutes until they are soft enough. Be mindful not to cook them too long as they will burn.

Cook the salmon. To plate, simply place the roasted vegetables in a nice fashion like what is seen in the video. Place the salmon on top. Then use a serving pot to pour in the broth like how they do it in a fine dining restaurant. The beetroot will also slowly give the broth a bright Ferrari red colour. And voila, a beautiful delicious salmon in vegetables broth dish.

This way, we can still enjoy a really fine dining dish at home :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets, and wait for the separate salmon video later.

caption:
Stuffed Squid with Glutinous Rice.

Soak 100g of glutinous rice for 2 hours. Also soak 2 dried Chinese mushrooms for an hour and retain the mushroom water. Boil a lup cheong or Chinese sausage for a minute to help to remove the skin easily.

Dice the sausage, along with a clove of garlic. In a wok of oil, dry the garlic, sausage and a handful of dried shrimp until it’s temptingly aromatic.

Then add the glutinous rice and mix well. Season with 1 tsp light soya, 1 tsp dark soya, 1 tsp sesame oil, 1 tsp Chinese wine and some white pepper. Stir well.

Add some of the mushroom water and let the rice absorb the liquid until there’s no water left in the wok. Pour the rice into a bowl and steam it for 25 minutes.

Prepared 2 squids (we using the very fresh and plump ones from @lyhseafood) by removing the head and bones inside the body. Make sure to wash the insides thoroughly to remove and excess squid ink and any parts. You can choose to remove the skin if you like.

Spoon the rice into each squid and make sure they are evenly distributed along the length of the squid body. Do not stuff too tightly also as the squid will shrink, just ensure there’s enough ratio of rice to squid inside.

Sprinkle some chopped scallion and garlic. Drizzle a simple sauce comprising of 3 tsp water, 1 tsp light soya, 1/2 tsp sesame oil and 1/2 tsp Chinese wine. Then steam the squid for 4 or 5 minutes as squid cooks very fast.

Once it is done, the squid will look tighter due to the shrinkage. Simply cut into squid ring portions and enjoy! :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
A nourishing slow cooked soup tonight of pork ribs, snow pear, sweet dates, kernel almonds and white fungus, brewed for the better part of a day in our trusty slow cooker.

So much natural sweetness that even the little ones will take to this easily we think :)))))

Rice Cooker Dumplings, a ba zhang shortcut hack.

We have some balance of the rice dumpling filling from last week so decided to do a shortcut version for those who find it challenging to tie the actual ones.

Just a quick recap of the meat fillings - In a fresh wok of oil, fry another 3 minced garlic, a handful of dried shrimp and 1 chopped shallot until fragrant. Add the marinated pork, peanuts, dried mushrooms and chestnuts. Fry and stir until everything is properly mixed. After about 5 minutes, set aside and let it cool down. Soak one cup of glutinous rice overnight.

To a cup of water, add 1 tsp light soya, 1 tsp dark soya, 1 tsp oyster sauce, 1 tsp sesame oil and a dash of five spice powder. Stir well.

Add the soaked rice to a rice cooker and pour in the soya mixture and stir a bit. Let it cook in rice cooker until it’s fully cooked.

Put a cling wrap into a bowl to prevent sticking as glutinous rice is rather sticky. Spoon enough rice to cover one third of the bowl. Then add in the meat filling and fill the rest of the bowl with rice to cover.

On a plate, it’s optional to put a few bamboo leaves as this will rather give a more zhang vibe. Flip the bowl over onto the plate and gently lift at the sides and you should see a cutesy round shaped rice dumpling.

It should taste similar sans the boiled bamboo fragrance, though you can always boil the leaves too to get that aroma. :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Almond Butter Notella Braided Swirl Bread.

In a bread maker, add 280g bread flour, 50g butter, 3 tbsp sugar, 1 tsp salt, 1/2 egg and 160ml milk. Add in 1 tsp instant yeast and set it to bread mode and let the bread maker work it’s magic

Once it’s finished, pour the dough onto a flour dusted table and roll it out with a rolling pin into a flat squarish shape. Apply half of it with almond butter and another half with notella. You can use normal Nutella for an unhealthy rendition.

Then slowly roll up the dough from the bottom to eventually form a cylindrical shape. See the video to see how to use a dough cutter to make an incision right down the center to expose the nut butter cross section and into two ends. Leave the top section uncut.

Take each side of each end and cross over the other like tying a shoe lace. Again refer to the video. You will end up with a braided looking bread shape like what you see in the video.

Rest for 45 minutes in a warm enough environment. Then bake at 180 Celsius no fan for 20 minutes. At the end, healthy almond butter notella braided swirl bread that will look visually arresting also :)))))

caption:
A simple and refreshing dinner of herbal chicken mee sua.

Just a simple steamed boneless chicken leg with Angelica root, goji berries, dried scallops and red dates. Season with salt, pepper, Chinese wine and sesame oil. Let it steam in a wok for about 25 minutes.

After steaming, simply slice the chicken into slices, and seen here served with mee sua and a side of dried shrimp cabbage. We finished it in minutes :)))))

Kimchi Fried Rice, easy and delicious.

Here’s how to do this at home, you need to have kimchi of course, which you can easily procure at the local supermarkets. And as an optional extra, we are using smoked bratwurst though bacon or luncheon meat will do just as well.

Have some cooked rice ready, and contrary to popular belief, you don’t need to use overnight rice. What you can do is to cook the rice a few hours in advance, and once it’s cook, open the lid and let it dry out for an hour to 2. The key is to remove any excess moisture so that the rice won’t be clumpy when fried.

Start in a wok with some oil and fry the meat chopped in small dices. Fry a few minutes until it’s lightly browned. If your kimchi is still in large pieces, make sure to cut them into smaller and thinner slices beforehand.

Add the kimchi, as to how much it’s up to you. We would suggest about 2 handfuls should be sufficient but go crazy with more if you adore the Korean pickled cabbage.

Stir and mix well with the meat. We add a canned tomato and some of the juices to give it some hearty acidity, but you can substitute with Korean gochujang sauce for an extra spicy kick.

Next add the rice and stir well. Use a spatula to break up any clumpy rice and get every grain properly coated with the kimchi sauce. It should look bright red when it’s done. 
Add a dash of sesame oil and chopped scallion. Turn off the flame and serve. We are using a shallow cast iron pan as it resembles those metal pans that Korean places usually use.

For garnishing, cut a dried seaweed sheet into very thin strips and place in the center of the rice. Then sprinkle some white sesame seeds and you are done! And just to make it more Korean, stick 2 long spoons at opposite sides of the pan.

Add a sunny side egg as an extra and enjoy the simple but highly tasty fried rice :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

Doesn’t this make you want to watch Kdramas now? We highly recommend shows like Healer, Pinocchio and Coffee Prince. And DOTS of course where we first saw this dish hehe.

caption:
Homemade Ondeh Ondeh, also known as Klepon in Indonesia.

Start by opening a packet of grated coconut, which you can get from @redmartcom. Break it into pieces as it’s probably quite hardened when you open. Add half tsp salt. Steam the coconut on a plate in a wok for about 15 minutes. Set aside for later.

Cut about 12 pandan leaves into shorter lengths and add them to a blender with about 100ml water. Blitz until you get pandan juice. Strain the juice. Chop palm sugar or gula melaka into small chunks. You can buy this from @redmartcom also.

In a whisking bowl, add 100g glutinous rice flour, 40g tapioca flour, 2 tbsp sugar and the strained pandan juice. Use a spatula to mix until you get an Incredible Hulk green dough. Knead until it’s smooth all around.

Then tear the dough into roughly 20g sized pieces, each making one Ondeh ball. Flatten it and add a piece of palm sugar and fold until you cover the sugar. Roll into a round ball. You should be able to make a dozen balls.

Boil a pot of water and add the balls into the bubbling water. It will initially sink to the bottom of the pot. It will need between 10 to 15 minutes to fully cook the Ondeh balls.

Around 10 mins or so, the balls will start to float up. Let it cook another 2 to 5 minutes to allow the gula melaka to fully melt inside. Once it’s cooked, strain the balls of excess water.

Put the balls in a plate with the grated coconut and roll them until they are fully coated. After which, simply serve in a plate.

It should be pandan chewy bouncy on the outside. Inside, it should also be palm sugary lava gooey inside, and that combination of flavours and texture is what fans of this will swoon over :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Japanese Kare Udon, Curry Noodles.

Here’s a quick and tasty meal to whip up in minutes during this circuit breaker light period. Just get these items from @shinsengrocer - ready to eat Japanese curry, or Kare as they call it, their tasty gyo or fish udon and a chicken fillet. We always like the superb ones from @benjachickensingapore.

Lightly blanche the udon for a minute and set aside. Then chop the chicken into chunks and fry them in a pan of oil until they brown and is fully cooked. Takes about 5 minutes or more at medium heat.

Then add the Japanese curry. Normally you need to cook the vegetables separately and add a Japanese curry cube to make the curry, but @shinsengrocer has done all that. 
Usually you will eat this with rice, but trust us, it’s even better with noodles. So simply add the readymade curry into the pan with the chicken and mix them up well.

Next, just the udon and toss until they are evenly coated and you are done! Simply serve into bowls and garnish with a little scallion for colour. And enjoy :)))))

Quattro Formaggi Pizza with Porcini and Truffle Paste, four cheese goodness,

Using the same pizza recipe from the original margherita pizza from a few days back, we replaced the tomato filling with a gorgeous four cheese and porcini one. Here’s a recap of the dough recipe.

Dissolve 1 tsp instant yeast to 160ml warm water. In a mixing bowl, add 250g plain flour and 1/2 tsp salt. Stir to mix well. Then slowly add the yeast mixture into the flour until they are fully integrated. Stir to form a shaggy dough.

Once you get that wet dough, pour it out onto a flour dusted table. Then knead until you form a smooth dough ball. Cover with a damp cloth and let it rest in a warm place for about 2 hours.

After resting, cut the dough into halves. Each half will make one pizza base. Shape each dough into another dough ball and then rest for another 2 hours.

After the dough ball has rested enough, place it on a flour dusted table again. Punch it down with your fist to flatten it. Then spread it out as much as you can. You can hold it in the air with both hands and just roll it like you see in the video.

Once it’s thin enough and it’s the size of a regular pizza shape, place the dough on a round baking pan. Add four different cheeses, we chose parmigiana reggiano, cheddar, mozzarella and gruyere cheese.

In addition, we soaked some dry porcini for half an hour and placed the soak porcini around the pizza, and drizzled some of the porcini water around too. To make it even more luxurious, we added some truffle paste from @shinsengrocer.

Bake it in a preheated oven at 250 Celsius or at your highest available temperature for 8 to 10 minutes. When the cheese has completely melted and has a light golden crust, remove from oven.

It should look like golden brown cheese nirvana and the lovely aroma of melted cheese and porcini, and should be delicious to cheese lovers everywhere :)))))

caption:
Saturday Waffles with Candied Bacon and Scrambled Eggs.

Make your candied bacon by spreading sugar over strips of bacon and baking them in the oven at 190 Celsius for 12 minutes.

To make the batter for waffles, which 1 cup plain flour, 2 tsp baking powder, 1 tsp sugar, 3 tbsp coconut oil, 1 cup milk and 1 tbsp water until you form a smooth batter.

Simply pour the batter into your waffle maker and let it cook until it’s done. Yums, the smell of fresh waffles on a weekend morning is just so good.

Cook some scrambled eggs which you can find in another post here, just have to scroll back to find it hehe. Then just add the eggs and bacon to your freshly made waffles.

It’s a simple and easy to do waffle breakfast that will surely please the family :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Seafood Claypot Noodles using leftover bkt broth from @songfabkt.

Don’t throw away excess bkt broth next time you order this at home, as the tasty soup can make for an even tastier dish the next day. We had some leftover from yesterday to make this claypot noodles even better.

Cook some claypot noodles by blanching in water for a few minutes until they turn soft. Then fry half a sliced onion in oil until fragrant. Again, we had some leftover onion from lunch.

Add about 4 scallops that have been cut into halves. Stir and toss for awhile. Then add some fish chunks. We still had some batang leftover from last week’s army stew, and they still taste fresh. Again, kudos to @lyhseafood for giving us such good produce.

Stir and toss again, then add the blanched noodles and stir/toss again. Next, season with a tbsp light soya and some white pepper. Add some broth, and we using the delicious peppery bkt broth from @songfabkt from yesterday’s lunch.

Let the noodles braise for a short while. Transfer to a claypot on a stove and cover for a minute or so until it boils. When it reaches an enticing claypot bubbling boil, remove and serve.

As you can tell, we are using a lot of leftovers tonight, which is a great way to save costs and avoid food wastage. At the same time, the dinner still tastes fresh and delicious :)))))

caption:
Mount Karubi Don - Homemade Wagyu Beef Rice Bowl.

Here’s how you can assemble your own wagyu don at home without breaking the bank. We happen to have some excellent beef short ribs from @yakiniku_plaza.

Cook some white rice. In a pan of oil, fry half an onion that has been sliced. Fry until they are soft and translucent. Once they are caramelised, they will be gorgeously sweet. Season with a tbsp light soya and one tbsp mirin. Set aside.

You can use any beef shabu for this also, but it’s better to get a thicker cut ones. The better the quality the beef, the better this rice bowl will turn out.

Season with just some sea salt and black pepper. At home, it’s hard to replicate a proper charcoal fire yakiniku experience, so we settled for a grill pan. Though any pan will do, just that you can get nice grill marks from a grill pan.

Get the pan nice and hot, and simply cook it for a minute or less each side. Don’t add  oil especially for wagyu cuts as they have enough fat on it’s own, and don’t overcook. Beef this thin and good, you want to preserve the tender moist texture and flavours.

Once the beef is cooked, time to plate up. In a bowl of rice, layer the caramelised onions first, followed by placing the beef slices around the onions to form a mountain shape. See the video for this.

Then just add some more onions and garnish with either scallions or leeks. Sprinkle some furikake for that complete Japanese feel and voila, Mount Karubi Don is born :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Eating healthy is something we always advocate, and cooking at home is one way to ensure healthier standards around the household.

We also like to start our day with an energy boosting one with lots of vitamins and nutrients, and a good dose of probiotics.

Hence, today is Chobani Greek yogurt parfait, homemade matcha granola and a variety of citrus fruits :)))))

Taking it easy tonight with a simple 8 hour slow cooker soup.

Just put pork ribs, longan, couple of corn 🌽 and carrots into a slow cooker for 8 hours. A nourishing and naturally sweet broth for the day :)))))
comments: ['the color of that soup is amazing!!! cant imagine how good this tastes😍', 'Oh that soup looks like pure gold!', '👍', 'Must be super sweet 😋 I love corn in my slow cooked soups']

caption:
Simple Nonya Curry Chicken using the curry powder from @shermayssingaporefinefood.

Start by blitzing one garlic, one shallot and a few slices of ginger into a paste. Use half of a packet of @shermayssingaporefinefood Nonya Curry Chicken powder which is enough for 2 persons. Pour half the packet into 150ml water and stir well to dissolve the powder.

Add the minced garlic, shallot and ginger into the curry mixture. Then pour this mixture into a bowl of 250g chicken. We using chicken wings today. Use your hands to marinate the chicken evenly and thoroughly. Rest for 20 minutes.

Fry one chopped onion in a wok of oil until fragrant. Once the onions are soft, add in the chicken and 2 chopped potatoes. Mix well before pouring in the rest of the chicken marinate and add enough water to cover the chicken.

Season with about a tsp of salt for taste. Then leave it to gently simmer for at least half an hour to cook the chicken and for the potatoes to get soft.

After half an hour, add in either coconut cream or milk to thicken the curry and make it creamy or lemak. Turn off the flame and serve. Easy and tasty :)))))
