caption:
When you can’t get enough of HK French Toasts especially during this stay home time, you make your own.

Get thick toasts for this though any normal white bread can still work. We using our homemade Hokkaido milk bread which is even more delicious.

First, trim off the crust edges. Use 2 slices for each hk toast. Spread smooth peanut butter on both slices, we using the healthy almond one from @scoopwholefoods_sg. Cover and make the egg coating.

Add 3 tbsp of fresh milk to 3 eggs and beat them well. Use a wide enough plate or pan that can hold the width of your toast. Get your oil hot and ready first before you coat as this is crucial.

Use a pot wide enough to hold the toast and allow it to turn on its sides. Heat up the oil to 150 Celsius. To test, drop a few drops of the egg coat and it should sizzle and fry into a batter almost instantly.

Set the stove to medium heat. Coat the toast with the egg solution on every side evenly. Each side only a few seconds as the idea is not to let it soak too much for too long. Once it’s all coated, immediately drop it into the pot of bubbling oil.

Each side should only take 30 seconds to get brown. You should get crusty fried egg shards on the sides, this will be so delicious! Use tongs to flip to the edges to get all 6 sides fully fried. On the last side, which should be the other flat side, set heat to maximum to get full deep fry mode. This will allow the toast not to get too much excess oil.

Drain the toast on paper towels to remove any last bit of oil. To finish, add a thick slice of cold butter and drizzle cold maple syrup on top and you are down! It may be called French toast, and as much as I regard French cooking, this is one thing that Asians are much better at pulling off :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.
comments: ['Agree ❤️', 'Yummy.. peanut butter in the middle is a game changer', '@hellosam8', 'Going to do this today! 好味😋', 'Yummy 😍', '❤️❤️❤️']

caption:
Bak Zhang Rice Dumplings.

Dragon Boat Festival is just around the corner and with saving costs foremost on our minds, we decided to make our own instead of buying from outside.

Start by soaking 500g glutinous rice, 12 chestnuts and bamboo leaves overnight. Also, soak about 6 dried mushrooms for 2 hours.

Marinate 250g pork shoulder or belly with 1 tbsp light soya, 1 tbsp dark soya, 1 tbsp sesame oil, 1 tbsp oyster sauce, 3 minced garlic, 1 chopped shallot and some 5 spice powder. Add a dash of white pepper also.

In a wok of oil, fry 3 minced garlic and 1 chopped shallot until fragrant. Add the glutinous rice and mix well. Season with 1 tbsp light soya, 1 tbsp dark soya, 1 tbsp sesame oil, 1 tbsp oyster sauce and some 5 spice powder. Stir until the rice is evenly coated, then set aside and let it cool down.

In a fresh wok of oil, fry another 3 minced garlic, a handful of dried shrimp and 1 chopped shallot until fragrant. Add the marinated pork, dried mushrooms and chestnuts. Fry and stir until everything is properly mixed. After about 5 minutes, set aside and let it cool down.

For each dumping take 2 bamboo leaves and fold at the center to form a triangle cup as seen in the video. Spoon some rice to fill one third of the capacity. Add a chestnut and a piece of pork.

Then add a chestnut, half a mushroom, some braised peanuts (from can) and half a salted egg yolk. You can also add an abalone as an option.

Fold the the flap of the lead to cover the base of the dumpling and fold in any other flap. Ensure it is tight and there are no gaps to form a taut pyramid shape.

We tie the dumpling strings to a hangar, but you can improvise with whatever is convenient. Use the string to tie around the dumpling and ensure it is tight. Make 12 dumplings with this recipe.

Then boil the dumplings in a wok of water for 45 minutes and it should be done. If you didn’t leave any gaps, the dumpling should look firm and neat.

We still need more practice with our dumpling tying skills, but this way is certainly more affordable than buying commercial ones outside. And equally as tasty :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets

caption:
After cooking exclusively at home and making all our meals for 2 months, we decided to mark the end of cb with a meal from outside.

And thanks to our friends from @songfabkt, we had a marvelous Bak Kut Teh lunch with braised pig triggers and fried you tiao. When it comes to bkt, we still defer to them as they still have a fine balance of savoury, meaty, garlicky and peppery notes without being over-sweet.

And also, we are busy with making something today that we thought to take it easy for lunch :)))))

caption:
Cone Bread Rolls.

Freshly baked bread is the best thing to wake up to! And this is one simple and easy bread recipe to do at home.

In a bread maker, add 280g bread flour, 50g butter, 3 tbsp sugar, 2 tbsp milk powder, 1 tsp salt, 1/2 egg, 160ml water and 1 tsp instant yeast. Set to bread dough mode and let it start and work it’s way till it is done. If you don’t have a bread machine, you can knead mix and knead by hand or mixed too.

Once the dough is finished in the bread maker, pour it out onto a flour dusted table. Use a dough cutter to cut into 12 equal portions. Each portion will make one bread roll. 
Roll each portion into a dough ball. Cover with a cloth and rest for 15 minutes. After resting, roll out each ball into thin long shape as seen in the video.

Use a cone mold like seen in the video and twirl the cylinder like dough around the cone to form a bread roll cone. Then cover with cloth and rest for an hour.

After the second resting, bake in a preheated oven at 180 Celsius fan mode for 15 minutes or until it’s perfectly golden brown.

Remove and enjoy! It is good on it’s own and nothing smells like a perfect morning then the aroma of freshly baked bread. And ideal with a dollop of cold butter :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Pad Gaprao, or simply known as Thai Basil Minced Pork.

We often find this dish in Thai eateries, here’s how to make this simple dish at home. Gaprao is Thai for holy basil, which is different from the Italian basil we see in pasta. It has a more minty herbaceous aroma.

Start by making the sauce by adding together, 1 tbsp fish sauce, 1 tbsp light soya, 1 tbsp dark soya, 1 tbsp oyster sauce and 2 tbsp water. Optional add tbsp sugar. Mix well and set aside.

In a wok of hot oil, fry 2 minced garlic and 1 finely chopped chilli until they are fragrant. Add 200g to 250g minced pork and stir. Make sure to use a spatula to break out the meat to avoid clumps.

Once the meat has sufficiently browned, add the sauce and mix well until the meat is fully coated. Then add half a chopped onion and a handful of chopped long beans. Mix well again.

When the onions and long beans are soft, turn off the flame and add in a handful of Thai basil leaves. Toss quickly in the residual heat to somewhat blanche the basil. And that’s it, easy.

This is best eaten with white rice, so simply pour the Pad Gaprao over the rice and enjoy. It’s also nice to have a sunny side up egg with this too :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Crispy Salmon, how to get it right.

Always pat dry your salmon before cooking it, and make sure it’s at room temperature. So, don’t take it out from the refrigerator too late.

Season with sea salt is best, as the courser particles will not dissolve that fast and make it overly salty. Season liberally also with both salt and black pepper on both sides. Salt will also help to extract any additional moisture, and that will help in making the skin crispy.

In a pan with a generous amount of oil at medium heat, always make sure the pan is well heated up before putting the fish in. And always start with skin side down, and a good non stick pan is best.

Slide the pan a bit to maw sure the skin is not sticking to the pan, and also only to turn the fish once. Fish like salmon only takes 4 to 5 minutes at most. Which means it should take not more than 2.5 minutes for each side, which is sufficient to crisp up the skin.

Once the skin side is crispy, flip the fish over and drop a spoon of butter which will melt very quickly. Use a spoon to baste the fish like what you see in the video.

Use a pair of tongs to feel the sides of the fish. It should feel firmer than when it was raw, but not too tough until it’s hard. Once you get that nice firm and toi toi texture, remove the fish from the heat and let it rest for a few minutes.

Your salmon skin will also dry off and you will end up with a perfectly seared and crispy skin, and a flaky and slightly pink and moist, tender flesh inside :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Dutch Baby Pancake.

Not your regular pancakes, this is really delicious and looks so good. You will need a cast iron pan or a pan that can be baked in an oven as most standard pans have materials that are not conducive in an oven.

Warm up half a cup of milk. In a whisking bowl, add 1/2 cup plain flour, 1/2 cup warmed milk, 2 large eggs, 1/2 tsp salt and 2 tbsp sugar. Whisk until you get a smooth batter.

Heat up your 9 inch cast iron skillet in an oven until it’s piping hot. Drop 2 tbsp butter into it and it will immediately fizzle. Use a spoon to wipe the butter all around the pan. Immediately pour in the batter and spread it evenly around the skillet.

Bake the pancake in the pan in a preheated oven at 220 Celsius no fan for around 15 minutes. After 10 minutes, it should puff up considerably. Ensure the center is properly cooked and set before removing it from the oven.

Once you take the pancake out, dust some icing sugar on the base before adding fruits of your choice. Then dust some more icing sugar and add some maple syrup and it’s done! Delicious and full of fruit vitamins :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Homemade Margherita Italian Pizza.

This is easy and cheap to do at home. Now, we won’t be able to achieve charred crusts like those found in Italian woodfire pizza joints, but this is a home oven version using fresh ingredients and making pizza dough from scratch.

Dissolve 1 tsp instant yeast to 160ml warm water. In a mixing bowl, add 250g plain flour and 1/2 tsp salt. Stir to mix well. Then slowly add the yeast mixture into the flour until they are fully integrated. Stir to form a shaggy dough.

Once you get that wet dough, pour it out onto a flour dusted table. Then knead until you form a smooth dough ball. Cover with a damp cloth and let it rest in a warm place for about 2 hours.

After resting, cut the dough into halves. Each half will make one pizza base. Shape each dough into another dough ball and then rest for another 2 hours. In the meantime, make the tomato sauce.

The best tomatoes are the ones from San Marzano, but it’s hard to get those. Either get a good Italian canned tomatoes, but if not, just get any canned ones will do. Blitz 3 or 4 canned tomatoes until it turns into a paste. Season with 1/2 tsp salt, some oregano and a dash of extra virgin olive oil.

After the dough ball has rested enough, place it on a flour dusted table again. Punch it down with your fist to flatten it. Then spread it out as much as you can. You can hold it in the air with both hands and just roll it like you see in the video.

Once it’s thin enough and it’s the size of a regular pizza shape, place the dough on a round baking pan. Spoon the tomato sauce onto the pizza base and spread it with the base of a ladle evenly.

Next, add balls of mozzarella cheese all around the pizza and some basil leaves. Bake it in a preheated oven at 250 Celsius or at your highest available temperature for 8 to 10 minutes. When the cheese has completely melted and has a light golden crust, remove from oven.

Serve it on a board or plate and cut it with a pizza cutter and enjoy! Pizzas are best eaten when it’s piping hot, and that’s why having this, you are unlikely to go back to fast food ones :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Tom Yum Rice Cooker, a taste of Siam.

To make this, there’s 2 ways. One is to use our previous Tom Yum broth, which you can find by scrolling through our feed. The other much easier way is to use this organic Tom Yum paste which you find via @shermayssingaporefinefood and the associated online grocer.

Dissolve 2 tsp of the Tom Yum into a cup of warm water. Then pour the mixture into a rice cooker filled with a cup of rice. Good enough for 2 persons.

You can also to add some optional ingredients to make it even more fragrant. Crush some lemongrass with the back of a knife and chop them. Add to the rice cooker. Cut some slices of galangal and add them too.

Simply set to rice cooker mode and let it cook till it is done. In the meantime, you can marinate about 6 deshelled and deveined tiger prawns with 1 tsp fish sauce and some white pepper. Prepare some broccoli and cherry tomatoes as accompaniments.

When the rice is cooked, open the rice cooker and add the broccoli and tomatoes and cook for 5 minutes. Then open again and add the prawns and cook for 3 to 5 minutes until they are pinkly cooked. Add a tsp of fish sauce around the rice also when you add the prawns.

When the prawns are done, you can simply spoon everything into a bowl and garnish with some sliced green chilies and enjoy :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Cheaper to make our own açai at home.

Simply put two açai bars (can buy from redmart) for 2 portions and add one banana if you have. Remember that the açai is unsweetened so add as much sugar as you desire, but the banana is more than sweet enough for us.

We added some frozen raspberries into the blender and blitz. Once it’s fully blended, you should get açai the same as you would outside.

We had it with some konnyaku jelly and fruits this morning :)))))
comments: ['Hi, can you please post the video recipe for konnyaku jelly again?  Thank you.']

caption:
Simplest Chicken Stew Ever.

Using the leftover veggies from @greenies.sg, we dumped one big chicken leg, chopped potatoes, chopped celery, chopped carrots, sliced onions, canned tomatoes into our trusty little slow cooker.

Add enough water to cover the ingredients and let it slow cook for at least 8 hours. When you are ready to eat, just add enough salt to taste and break some basil leaves into the broth for a lovely herbaceous fragrance.

It will be just perfect for a hearty meal, and you can have it with baguette or rice. So refreshing after a day of wfh :)))))

caption:
Butadon with Egg.

When you see shabu shabu pork in supermarkets, don’t just think of using them for hotpot, as you will need to buy a bunch of other stuff just to do a hotpot. Instead here’s a simple rice bowl that’s fast and easy to whip up.

We are using the pork tricol roll from @yakiniku_plaza which you can go to for online home deliveries. They have a range of premium Japanese beef and pork items suited for simple yet tasty meals.

In a pan of oil at medium heat, sweat half a sliced onions until they are slightly charred, soft and translucent. Once they are soft, add your pork shabu into the mix. Use a pair of tongs to separate the pieces as they tend to stick together.

Once the meat is seared for about a minute or less, add 1 tbsp light soya (or 2 tbsp udon/soba sauce), 1 tbsp mirin, half tsp sugar and 2 tbsp water. Simmer for about a minute.

Turn the heat to low and add in one beaten egg and cover with lid for about 10 seconds. Open the lid and wait for the base of the egg to set and see that the egg is not watery. If it’s just moist, it will be fine as the egg will continue to cook on its own residual heat.

Pour the pork and egg mixture onto a bowl of white rice, preferably Japanese rice. Then garnish it with scallion and furikake and it’s done! Easy and delicious, and much more convenient than doing a steamboat :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
Here’s a recap of that famous grilled cheese sandwich as seen in the movie, Chef. And boy, is this so stretchy good.

Butter both slices of a bread, we doing this with our own Hokkaido milk bread yields the best result. We use ghee here cos it’s clarified and mighty delicious, especially with our local QBB green tin brand.

In a pan of oil at low to medium heat, put both slices in simultaneously, buttered side faced down. Rub a little of the oil to prevent sticking. Immediately add the cheeses. We chose gouda, emental, cheddar and mozzarella, but you can go crazy with your own combinations.

After about a minute, cover your cheeses with the other slice and butter the top of it again with more butter. Yes, butter is marvelous here as it gives tremendous flavor. Then after another minute, flip over and toast the other side good.

Then after another minute, your cheeses should melt nicely. Now, if your bread is a bit thick like ours, do not fret if the cheese takes longer to melt. Simply send to the oven at 220 Celsius and toast for another 5 minutes with a foil wrap to get that final melting done.

Once the cheese has melted, then comes the really fun part. Cut into half and hear that symphony of crust crackling. Then, pull them apart for that cheesy stretch effect, fantastic for that instagram video.

But the true test is that first bite, crispy crackling of bread in your mouth up to your eardrums. And that combination of umami cheese goodness, and that buttery toast sensation. The kind of breakfast to salivate over, so go make some now yourself :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.

caption:
A healthy Sunday start with Chobani Greek yoghurt, fruits and homemade matcha granola. Here’s how to make fresh and healthy matcha infused granola at home.

All you need is to mix 1 cup rolled oats, 1/2 cup unsalted and unsweetened almond + cashew + hazelnuts, 1/2 cup pine + chia seeds, 1/2 tsp salt, 2 tsp matcha power, 2 tbsp coconut oil and 2 tbsp honey in a mixing bowl.

After a good mix, roll out the mixed granola onto a baking tray lined with baking paper. Spread it out evenly to cover every corner. Then send it to the oven for 15 minutes at 180 Celsius at no fan mode. Every five minutes, just stir it around to prevent any burning.

Once it’s nicely toasted, take it out of the oven and add some dried sultana, freeze dried strawberries and cacao nibs to complete this crunchy and nutritious granola. Pour it all into a glass jar and you can use it for many days of breakfast :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the granola video snippets.

Crispy Salmon in Vegetable Broth.

Thanks to our friends at @greenies.sg, we had a bounty of vegetables and fruits today, and what’s fun about them is they also cut some of these veggies for you, making it easier to work with.

And the first thing we thought of to maximize such nice vegetables was to make a delicious vegetable broth to go with a crispy pan seared salmon. We will show the salmon searing technique separately so watch for this in a later post.

To make the stock, simply put in a slow cooker, a chopped onion, a few stalks of chopped celery, one chopped carrot and some white cabbage. Add water to fill up the pot and set to slow cook for at least 8 hours. You can do this in pot over a stove also, just be mindful to top up water every once in a while.

We will not eat or use the vegetables in the slow cooker. The veggies we use in the actual dish will be roasted instead, as they taste amazingly tasty sweet when you cook them this way.

Slice the vegetables very thinly so you can roast them quickly without burning them. Lay these potatoes neatly on a baking tray lined with aluminum foil. Potatoes, carrots, celery, broccoli and beetroot.

Season them with sea salt and drizzle with olive oil. Roast in the oven at 200 Celsius for between 10 to 12 minutes until they are soft enough. Be mindful not to cook them too long as they will burn.

Cook the salmon. To plate, simply place the roasted vegetables in a nice fashion like what is seen in the video. Place the salmon on top. Then use a serving pot to pour in the broth like how they do it in a fine dining restaurant. The beetroot will also slowly give the broth a bright Ferrari red colour. And voila, a beautiful delicious salmon in vegetables broth dish.

This way, we can still enjoy a really fine dining dish at home :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets, and wait for the separate salmon video later.

caption:
Stuffed Squid with Glutinous Rice.

Soak 100g of glutinous rice for 2 hours. Also soak 2 dried Chinese mushrooms for an hour and retain the mushroom water. Boil a lup cheong or Chinese sausage for a minute to help to remove the skin easily.

Dice the sausage, along with a clove of garlic. In a wok of oil, dry the garlic, sausage and a handful of dried shrimp until it’s temptingly aromatic.

Then add the glutinous rice and mix well. Season with 1 tsp light soya, 1 tsp dark soya, 1 tsp sesame oil, 1 tsp Chinese wine and some white pepper. Stir well.

Add some of the mushroom water and let the rice absorb the liquid until there’s no water left in the wok. Pour the rice into a bowl and steam it for 25 minutes.

Prepared 2 squids (we using the very fresh and plump ones from @lyhseafood) by removing the head and bones inside the body. Make sure to wash the insides thoroughly to remove and excess squid ink and any parts. You can choose to remove the skin if you like.

Spoon the rice into each squid and make sure they are evenly distributed along the length of the squid body. Do not stuff too tightly also as the squid will shrink, just ensure there’s enough ratio of rice to squid inside.

Sprinkle some chopped scallion and garlic. Drizzle a simple sauce comprising of 3 tsp water, 1 tsp light soya, 1/2 tsp sesame oil and 1/2 tsp Chinese wine. Then steam the squid for 4 or 5 minutes as squid cooks very fast.

Once it is done, the squid will look tighter due to the shrinkage. Simply cut into squid ring portions and enjoy! :))))) Check out my profile story highlights for the full video snippets.
